headline: TURKS TO VOTE ON EASING POLITICAL-ACTION CURB
abstract: LEAD: After weeks of wrangling, Turkish politicians have agreed on terms for a referendum later this year that is supposed to advance the nation's return to full democracy.

headline: MANY LAWMAKERS BACK MISSILE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: As Congress and the White House returned to work today from Easter vacation, lawmakers from both parties expressed support for a proposal the Soviet Union made during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit last week to eliminate short- and medium-range missiles from Europe.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Banner Industries, Cleveland, a supplier of aviation products, named as a director Donald Taylor, chairman of Rexnord Inc., a subsidiary acquired by Banner in March.

headline: Market Place; Technicians Are Sanguine
abstract: LEAD: ANY time the stock market takes a terrific jolt - as it did on Monday with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 57.39 points - investors like to know what Wall Street's technical analysts see ahead.

headline: KEY NORTH MEMO ALTERED BY HALL
abstract: LEAD: Fawn Hall, describing Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North as ''every secretary's dream of a boss,'' gave new details today of how she helped him alter, shred or remove documents implicating him in the Iran-contra affair.

headline: NEIGHBORS UNCAP THEIR PENS
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is to visit Rumania this month, and Hungarian analysts say they believe that his agenda is likely to include the issue of undisguised tension between two members of the Soviet bloc, Hungary and Rumania.

headline: U.S. and New Zealand Stop Aid to Fiji to Protest Coup
abstract: LEAD: The United States and New Zealand have suspended aid to Fiji to protest the coup that ousted an elected Government, officials said today.

headline: Trust Unit In Merger Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Wilmington Trust Company said today that it offered to merge with the Delaware Trust Company through an exchange of common stock valued at about $200 million.

headline: U.S.-INDIA RELATIONS ARE WORSENING, MOSTLY OVER PAKISTAN
abstract: LEAD: A series of major and minor disputes have sent relations between the United States and India skidding to the lowest level since Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi took office in 1984, American and Indian officials said today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Aloha Inc., Honolulu, parent of Aloha Airlines, named Sheridan C. F. Ing chairman of both the parent company and the airline. He succeeds Dr. Hung Wo Ching.

headline: A PROGRAM THAT TRIES TO TALK BACK
abstract: LEAD: THE screen greeted me with the title ''Thoughtline Computer Intelligence for Business Communications,'' followed by ''Hi - I'm Thoughtline, the intelligent writers companion.'' There was no apostrophe to be seen. ''I assume you are about to put your thoughts in writing,'' the screen continued. ''You can converse with me in free text by typing in normal English sentences.

headline: Tech Giveaway
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: ORANGES, LEMONS AND CARAMBOLAS
abstract: LEAD: MARC and Kiki Ellenby have seen the future and it is filled with carambolas, millions of pounds of them.

headline: Zenith Ruling
abstract: LEAD: Zenith Laboratories Inc. said a civil action against it by the Bristol-Myers Company charging infringement of a patent had been terminated by a consent order by the United States District Court for New Jersey. As previously reported, Bristol-Meyers charged that Zenith had infringed on its patent covering a form of Cefadroxil, an antibiotic.

headline: TRIANGLE PARK: NORTH CAROLINA'S HIGH-TECH PAYOFF
abstract: LEAD: AZT was all but forgotten, an ineffective cancer drug, when the Burroughs Wellcome Company moved its North American headquarters and research laboratories in 1970 from New York's Westchester County to the Research Triangle Park near here.

headline: G.N.P. RATE UP TO 4.4% IN QUARTER
abstract: LEAD: The economy, powered by strong auto production and an improving trade deficit, grew at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year, slightly better than previously thought, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: TAKING FARFLUNG POLITICS TO THE OUTER HEBRIDEANS
abstract: LEAD: On a day of rare warmth and brilliance for this misty island that makes its living off pen-raised salmon and Harris Tweed, Dr. David Owen tackled yet again the most daunting task in British politics. He was trying to talk people into voting for a third party that offers little hope of an outright victory.

headline: PURCHASING MANAGERS REPORT ECONOMIC GAINS
abstract: LEAD: The economy's rate of growth increased sharply in May, according to a monthly report released today by the National Association of Purchasing Managers.

headline: WPP Extends Bid
abstract: LEAD: WPP Group, the British marketing specialty company that is trying to acquire the JWT Group, parent of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, said it was extending until Monday at noon its $50.50-a-share offer originally made in a letter Wednesday and already extended once. According to a WPP spokesman, the two companies were in communication yesterday.

headline: U.S. and Syria Agree to Hold Talks, Officials Say
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan urged President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to begin high-level talks on a range of issues, including gaining the freedom of American hostages held in Lebanon, and Mr. Assad has agreed, Administration officials said today.

headline: IN BRAZIL, BATTLE OF THE BLOATED BUREAUCRACY
abstract: LEAD: When Wellington Moreira Franco took over as Governor of Rio de Janeiro on March 15, he learned to his surprise that his predecessor had handed out thousands of new permanent jobs in the state government just hours before he stepped down.

headline: PRICES INCREASED 0.4% IN MARCH FOR CONSUMERS
abstract: LEAD: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed indicator of inflation, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department reported today. On an annual basis, the increases so far this year translate into an inflation rate of 6.2 percent.

headline: Minstar's Gain On Borg-Warner
abstract: LEAD: Minstar Inc. said it had realized an after-tax gain of about $5 million, or 29 cents a share, from the sale last month of its interest in the Borg-Warner Corporation.

headline: Deal for A.M.C. Delayed Again
abstract: LEAD: The acquisition of the American Motors Corporation by the Chrysler Corporation has been delayed again, but Chrysler executives say they are still optimistic that an agreement can be reached.

headline: IN THE GORBACHEV MOLD: ALEKSANDR NIKOLAYEVICH YAKOVLEV
abstract: LEAD: During the summit meeting in Iceland last year, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev engaged in a low-key, private talk with American officials that resulted in a quick deal to stop the jamming of some American radio broadcasts to the Soviet Union.

headline: Treasury Issues Rise Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Strength in the dollar continued to spill over into the bond market, where prices of Treasury issues rose modestly in light trading yesterday.

headline: U.S. BOND PRICES END HIGHER
abstract: LEAD: Treasury bond prices gyrated wildly yesterday, falling sharply early in the day but recovering during the afternoon to end the day with modest gains.

headline: SOUTH KOREA CHIEF MEETS KEY LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
abstract: LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan met today with Kim Young Sam, president of the main opposition party, and held crucial talks aimed at ending South Korea's civil disorders.

headline: CAPACITY USE DOWN TO 78.9%
abstract: LEAD: The nation's industrial operating rate was just 78.9 percent of capacity in April, the poorest showing in more than three years, the Government reported today.

headline: Panel Gets Testimony By Levine
abstract: LEAD: Members of a Congressional subcommittee investigating the insider-trading scandals on Wall Street said today that they would focus their inquiry on the role of Dennis B. Levine's supervisors at the Wall Street firms where he worked.

headline: Allegheny Investor May Seek New Bid
abstract: LEAD: Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York-based investment partnership with a stake in Allegheny International Inc., said it might seek new bidders for the Pittsburgh-based appliance manufacturer.

headline: Market Place; Some Choices For 2d Quarter
abstract: LEAD: A HOST of special-situation stocks deserve a closer look this quarter, according to some portfolio managers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Burlington Industries has filed with the S.E.C. for $100 million of sinking-fund debentures, due in 2017, and $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2012.

headline: SURVIVORS OF ATTACK IN SRI LANKA TELL OF 'CALM, DISCIPLINED' KILLERS
abstract: LEAD: What V. B. Jayasuriya remembers most clearly was the cool, businesslike way the massacre happened.

headline: CAPE TOWN POLICE, USING BIRDSHOT, ARE SAID TO WOUND 8 ON CAMPUS
abstract: LEAD: The police opened fire with birdshot today in a running hourlong battle with 350 protesting students on the University of Cape Town campus.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: AUSTRIA, AFTER BAN ON WALDHEIM, ACTS TO LIMIT DAMAGE TO U.S. TIES
abstract: LEAD: The Austrian Government moved today to limit damage to its relations with Washington after President Kurt Waldheim was barred from the United States.

headline: Japan Moving to Open Markets to Foreigners
abstract: LEAD: A senior Japanese official today disclosed that Japan was taking further steps to open its financial markets to American and other foreign institutions.

headline: CAMPAIGN OVER, BRITAIN VOTES FOR A NEW PARLIAMENT TODAY
abstract: LEAD: Britain today reached the end of a general election battle in which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was tested by predictable attacks on her vision of the nation's future and by a surprisingly erratic performance by her own troubled campaign organization.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  International Report

headline: 7.3% of Spectradyne Now Held by Davis
abstract: LEAD: Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman and investor, said yesterday that he had raised his stake in Spectradyne Inc. to 7.3 percent, or 688,200 shares, from 5.7 percent.

headline: I.M.F. AND WORLD BANK SEEN SWAPPING ROLES
abstract: LEAD: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are moving toward a dramatic reversal of roles that is likely to change for years to come the manner in which developing nations obtain loans essential to their economic growth.

headline: REAGAN WAS TOLD IN '85 OF PROBLEM IN MOSCOW EMBASSY
abstract: LEAD: A secret report sent to President Reagan by his advisory panel on intelligence two years ago warned that the United States Embassy in Moscow was vulnerable to Soviet espionage, Government officials said today.

headline: Debentures Issued By Ryder System
abstract: LEAD: The Ryder System Inc. is offering $100 million of 9 7/8 percent debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 9.901 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: PRICES OF METALS RISE AMID FEARS OF INFLATION
abstract: LEAD: These are the times that swell the hearts and fill the pockets of gold bugs, that hardy band of investors in precious metals who thrive on economic misery. While Wall Street may mock gold as a ''sterile investment'' or ''barbaric relic,'' the recent sharp rise in gold and silver prices has given investors in stocks and bonds much to worry about.

headline: ELECTION IS SNUFFED OUT AT INSTITUTE IN MOSCOW
abstract: LEAD: The 2,000 employees of the Transport Construction Research Institute here tried to conduct an election for a new director this spring, inspired by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for increased democracy.

headline: O.E.C.D. TOPICS: GROWTH AND DOLLAR
abstract: LEAD: When the economic and finance ministers of 24 industrial nations gather here this week, they will have three pressing matters on their minds: the slowdown in economic growth, the plummeting dollar and growing strains on world trade.

headline: U.N. Chief to See Waldheim
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is scheduled to visit Vienna next month for a narcotics conference, has accepted an invitation to dine with President Kurt Waldheim there on June 16, a United Nations official said today. The Secretary General has refused to comment on reports that Mr.

headline: TERRORIST GROUP REPORTED IN INDIA
abstract: LEAD: Indian and American authorities have tightened security at airports and at the United States Embassy after receiving reports that members of a Middle Eastern terrorist group entered India last month.

headline: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE SOUTHERN LEBANON
abstract: LEAD: Israeli jets attacked Palestinian targets in southern Lebanon again today. The police reported that 10 people were killed and 28 were wounded.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: May 22, 1987  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL  Economic Committee - 3 P.M.  Social Committee - 10:30 A.M and 3 P.M.  TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL  Meets at 10:30 A.M.

headline: A REBOUNDING PAN AM SEES BREAK-EVEN YEAR
abstract: LEAD: Executives at Pan American World Airways expect the airline to break even this year and the overall holding company to make a small profit.

headline: Comart Bought By KLP Group
abstract: LEAD: Comart Associates, a New York-based sales promotion company, has been acquired by Britain's KLP Group, which now claims to be the largest such company in the world.

headline: A GOVERNMENT STILL ELUDES ITALY
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister-designate Oscar Luigi Scalfaro gave up a four-day effort to form a new government today, making a June general election virtually certain.

headline: WALSH SAID TO STUDY OFFICIALS' TESTIMONY ON HELP FOR CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, is studying Congressional testimony by current and former Reagan Administration officials to see if they lied about aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Federal investigators.

headline: Digital Earnings Increase 81%
abstract: LEAD: With its attack on I.B.M. showing little sign of abating, the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday reported an 81 percent rise in net income, to $307.6 million, or $2.29 a share, from $170 million, or $1.32 a share, in the period a year earlier.

headline: THE BOOM IN POLITICAL CONSULTING
abstract: LEAD: SCOTT MILLER proudly displayed his company's new headquarters on 60th Street just off Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and the contrast with days past could not have been more striking. Where once the Sawyer/Miller Group Inc.'s 30 employees had toiled in cramped, windowless rooms, the new offices - replete with sleek black furniture and fresh maroon carpeting -abound with light, space and air.

headline: Careers; Volunteers Who Aid Scientists
abstract: LEAD: VOLUNTEERS for Earthwatch are seldom too young or too old.

headline: S.E.C. Acts On Unequal Stock Votes
abstract: LEAD: In a step that could remove a key defense against hostile takeovers, the Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a rule that would forbid corporate managements from diluting the voting rights of their existing shareholders by issuing new classes of stock with multiple voting powers.

headline: Floating Point Reports Loss
abstract: LEAD: Floating Point Systems Inc., a manufacturer of supercomputers and add-on processors based in Beaverton, Ore., today reported a $2.1 million loss for its second quarter, which ended April 30.

headline: DOW OFF 11.32 AS MARKET MOOD SHIFTS
abstract: LEAD: The stock market's mood turned a bit sour yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost ground for the second straight day.

headline: TURKS FINALLY ASK, ARE WE EUROPEANS OR WHAT?
abstract: LEAD: In a salon usually reserved for artistic debate, a group of 200 people gathered the other day to discuss a question that reflects a national enigma: Are Turks Europeans?

headline: BONN'S DIPLOMATS SAY PILOT IS CALM
abstract: LEAD: West German diplomats today visited the young pilot who flew from Finland to the Kremlin and described him as bearing up calmly after nearly four days in the K.G.B.'s Lefortovo Prison.

headline: 4 Killed in Afghan Fighting
abstract: LEAD: Anti-Communist fighters attacked several towns in Afghanistan over the weekend, killing at least four people and wounding six, the official Kabul radio reported.

headline: UNITED AIRLINES ATTACKS PILOT UNION LEADERSHIP
abstract: LEAD: United Airlines yesterday attacked the leadership of the 7,000-member pilots union for what it called a ''hate management campaign'' and called on pilots to ''set emotion aside and think about your career.''

headline: Debt Ratings Reduced At Middle South Units
abstract: LEAD: Senior debt ratings for subsidiaries of Middle South Utilities were reduced to speculative grade, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

headline: LEBANESE PREMIER IS ASSASSINATED IN COPTER BLAST
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Rashid Karami was assassinated today when an explosion attributed to a bomb ripped through a military helicopter in which he was traveling.

headline: China Needs Democracy, Dissident Says
abstract: LEAD: One of China's most prominent dissenters, who was expelled from the Communist Party last winter after nationwide student demonstrations, said today that China could not carry through its current modernization drive without true democracy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 23, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Agreement On Bank Bill
abstract: LEAD: House and Senate conferees agreed today to provisions of a banking bill that would give Federal regulators permanent authority to take over banks before they fail and to merge across state lines failing banks and their holding companies if their assets were more than $500 million.

headline: INDIA AND CHINA CITE EACH OTHER FOR MASSING TROOPS IN HIMALAYAS
abstract: LEAD: India and China are accusing each other of massing troops along their Himalayan border in northeastern India, heightening tension between Asia's biggest nations.

headline: U.S. Citizen From Texas Slain In China by Thieves on Train
abstract: LEAD: A Texan was stabbed to death last week during a robbery on a train bound from Beijing to Canton, according to the American Embassy and the Chinese police. Two men have been arrested.

headline: ANTIGUA IS SWEPT BY BUILDING BOOM
abstract: LEAD: Thirty-eight years ago Vernon Nicholson sailed to this Caribbean island with his wife and two sons aboard the 70-foot schooner Mollihawk, looking for a new life after serving as a British naval officer in World War II.

headline: Realty Developer Restructuring Debt
abstract: LEAD: The Southland Financial Corporation, a real estate development company in Irving, Tex., said it was working with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and La Salle Partners Ltd. in an attempt to restructure the company's debt obligations. Southland has said that it was trying to reduce its current interest expense and extend its principal repayment schedule.

headline: Castle & Cooke Studies Spinoff
abstract: LEAD: Castle & Cooke Inc. said that it is considering turning its Flexi-Van Leasing subsidiary into a separate, publicly traded company by selling the transportation equipment leasing unit to holders of its common and convertible preferred shares. David H. Murdock, Castle & Cook's chairman and chief executive, said at the company's annual meeting in Hawaii that Castle & Cook's financial position had improved steadily since it merged with Flexi

headline: Soviet Seeks to Resolve Property Issues in Israel
abstract: LEAD: Soviet officials have applied for visas to travel to Israel this summer to deal with consular issues, including Soviet-owned property, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said today.

headline: Bell & Howell Sale Of DeVry Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Bell & Howell Company, as part of its strategy to focus on its publishing and information-services operations, said it planned to sell its majority stake in DeVry Inc., a technical-school business, for $147.4 million. The sale of 85 percent of the unit to the Keller Graduate School of Management received Wall Street's approval.

headline: Barclays Names Chief Of North American Unit
abstract: LEAD: Barclays Bank said yesterday that it had named John A. Kerslake as chief executive of its North American operations.

headline: Students Clash With Police For 6th Day in South Korea
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of students battled policemen today in the sixth day of demonstrations demanding the ouster of President Chun Doo Hwan, witnesses said.

headline: U.S. Retaliates on Latest Asian Export: The Flying Roach
abstract: LEAD: Imagine a New York City cockroach with chutzpah. It has wings, a preference for bright lights and a sex drive so lusty it can produce 75 million offspring a year. That's the Asian roach, Blatella asahinai, and it has been vacationing in Florida this winter since arriving on cargo ships from Asia. It is expected to move north.

headline: Thompson Gets a Lift At Effies
abstract: LEAD: THE J. Walter Thompson Company, whose people could certainly use the boost in morale, took five gold prizes last night as the most effective advertising of 1986 was honored at the 19th annual Effie Awards at the New York Hilton.

headline: THE DAUNTING GANDHIS AND A DAUNTLESS CHALLENGER
abstract: LEAD: With a potential scandal and countless other headaches, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is receiving a constant thrashing from critics in Parliament. His critics have seldom had it so good.

headline: PENTAGON LINKING SECRET ARMY UNIT TO CONTRA MONEY
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon said today that it recently discovered that a secret Army unit disbanded in 1983 had set up a Swiss bank account that may later have been used illegally to finance arms for the Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: G.M.A.C. Plans For Home Equity
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation said it would begin offering home-equity financing to current G.M.A.C. customers in Illinois, Maryland and Michigan as a test market to be expanded if G.M.A.C. obtains state licensing.

headline: Saks, Field's Report 1986 Income Gains
abstract: LEAD: Saks Fifth Avenue and the Marshall Field's department stores each had 20 percent gains in operating income last year over 1985, and sales rose about 15 percent, their parent company, Batus Inc., said yesterday.

headline: JWT BOARD WAS GIVEN A TROUBLING REPORT
abstract: LEAD: In an appearance before JWT Group Inc.'s board in January, Joseph W. O'Donnell, then the recently appointed chairman of JWT's J. Walter Thompson Company, presented a letter with a list of 10 suspected financial irregularities he had found in the operation.

headline: PUTTING A KIWI IN EVERY LUNCH BOX
abstract: LEAD: WHAT drives the marketers is the dream of finding the next kiwi, the Horatio Alger of exotic fruit.

headline: A TIME TO TINKER WITH OPTIONS PLANS
abstract: LEAD: STOCK options have always come in a variety of shapes and sizes. There are qualified options, so-called because they ''qualified'' for tax-favored status. There are non-qualified options, on which corporations get a tax break but employees do not. And there are incentive stock options, particularly beloved by executives because they incur no tax when exercised and until recently were taxed at low capital gains rates when the stock was sold.

headline: PURCHASING AGENTS SAY ECONOMY GREW IN APRIL
abstract: LEAD: The economy continued to expand in April, with industrial companies reporting advances in employment and production, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its monthly report to be released today.

headline: SOFTWARE COPYRIGHT BILL MOVES AHEAD IN BRAZIL
abstract: LEAD: In a move aimed at settling a prolonged trade dispute with the United States, Brazil's Chamber of Deputies has approved a law accepting international copyright rules for computer software programs.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD:

headline: Salvador Amnesty Offer
abstract: LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte offered amnesty today to political prisoners and leftist guerrillas who join the democratic process. Mr. Duarte, in a speech marking the start of his fourth year in office, gave no details of the amnesty plan, and there was no immediate response from the various rebel groups that form the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.

headline: Witness Says She Saw Barbie Set Up Death Train
abstract: LEAD: A witness today told the court trying Klaus Barbie for crimes against humanity that she had seen the wartime Gestapo chief of this city personally organizing a deportation train from Lyons to Auschwitz that took about 600 people to their deaths.

headline: Borg Gives GAF Confidential Data
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers and investment bankers for the GAF Corporation have begun reviewing confidential data provided by the Borg-Warner Corporation to help GAF decide whether to pursue its interest in the industrial company, Wall Street sources said.

headline: PORTUGAL'S GOVERNMENT FALLS
abstract: LEAD: A censure vote on the economy today brought down Portugal's 16th Government since a military coup ended half a century of right-wing dictatorship in 1974.

headline: MOBIL SETS YIELDS
abstract: LEAD: The Mobil Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.70, to yield 8.32 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Noncallable for the life, the notes yield about 43-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Venice Moves to Limit Entrance of Tourists
abstract: LEAD: The government of this city so beloved by travelers acted today to limit the influx of tourists who come here to gaze at the canals and palaces.

headline: Article 173187 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's largest securities firm, lost about $100 million during the violent plunge in bond prices in April, according to analysts and Wall Street officials with knowledge of the firm's activities.

headline: British Television to Get Ads for U.S. Tourism
abstract: LEAD: The United States will be promoting tourism on TV in Britain for the first time beginning April 24.

headline: MONDAY TEXACO HEARING SET
abstract: LEAD: A Texas appeals court today granted a temporary injunction requested by Texaco Inc. that prevents the Pennzoil Company from seizing any Texaco assets at least until after a hearing set for next Monday in Houston.

headline: South Koreans Arrest 3 High Police Officials
abstract: LEAD: Three senior police commanders were arrested today on charges that they covered up information on the torture death of a student, officials said.

headline: Mazda Plans U.S. Parts Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it would invest $100 million to build a new parts-making plant near Detroit in partnership with three of its Japanese suppliers.

headline: OS/2 System: No Free Lunch
abstract: LEAD: When I.B.M.'s first generation of personal computers came out, the cost of buying the operating system - the program that acts as the computer's internal traffic cop, directing the flow of data and instructions - seemed inconsequential. I.B.M. charged about $40 for it; many computer dealers threw it in for free.

headline: A Briton Is to Head William M. Mercer
abstract: LEAD: William M. Mercer Inc., the largest of the concerns specializing in advising companies on employee benefits, announced yesterday that it had named Peter Coster, a Briton, to come to New York as its new president.

headline: 2 G.M. Closings To Affect 9,000
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said that it would close its Chevrolet-Pontiac-G.M. of Canada plants in Oklahoma City and Doraville, Ga., next week for inventory adjustment, temporarily laying off 9,000 workers.

headline: New Currency To Be Delayed
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury Department said today that technical problems would force a delay of up to two years in issuing the first redesigned American currency in a half-century.

headline: V.A. Raises Loan Rates
abstract: LEAD: The Veterans Administration is raising its maximum interest rate on federally backed V.A. mortgages one percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent, the first increase in two years.

headline: Chrysler-A.M.C. Tie Seen by August
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation expects to complete its takeover of the American Motors Corporation by Aug. 15, officials of Chrysler said. They also acknowledged that the 50-cents-a-share increase in the offer for the shares of A.M.C. was that company's price for co-operation in the merger. The board of the French auto maker Renault, which is A.M.C.

headline: Unisys Introduces Eight
abstract: LEAD: The Unisys Corporation introduced eight new models of its large A 15 mainframe computers. The company said that it had improved performance of the computers by an average of 20 percent.

headline: Fed Money Policy Unchanged
abstract: LEAD: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in early February, but they indicated that they were ready to tighten credit if forced to by economic conditions, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

headline: TURKS TO VOTE ON EASING POLITICAL-ACTION CURB
abstract: LEAD: After weeks of wrangling, Turkish politicians have agreed on terms for a referendum later this year that is supposed to advance the nation's return to full democracy.

headline: MANY LAWMAKERS BACK MISSILE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: As Congress and the White House returned to work today from Easter vacation, lawmakers from both parties expressed support for a proposal the Soviet Union made during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit last week to eliminate short- and medium-range missiles from Europe.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Banner Industries, Cleveland, a supplier of aviation products, named as a director Donald Taylor, chairman of Rexnord Inc., a subsidiary acquired by Banner in March.

headline: Market Place; Technicians Are Sanguine
abstract: LEAD: ANY time the stock market takes a terrific jolt - as it did on Monday with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 57.39 points - investors like to know what Wall Street's technical analysts see ahead.

headline: KEY NORTH MEMO ALTERED BY HALL
abstract: LEAD: Fawn Hall, describing Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North as ''every secretary's dream of a boss,'' gave new details today of how she helped him alter, shred or remove documents implicating him in the Iran-contra affair.

headline: NEIGHBORS UNCAP THEIR PENS
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is to visit Rumania this month, and Hungarian analysts say they believe that his agenda is likely to include the issue of undisguised tension between two members of the Soviet bloc, Hungary and Rumania.

headline: U.S. and New Zealand Stop Aid to Fiji to Protest Coup
abstract: LEAD: The United States and New Zealand have suspended aid to Fiji to protest the coup that ousted an elected Government, officials said today.

headline: Trust Unit In Merger Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Wilmington Trust Company said today that it offered to merge with the Delaware Trust Company through an exchange of common stock valued at about $200 million.

headline: U.S.-INDIA RELATIONS ARE WORSENING, MOSTLY OVER PAKISTAN
abstract: LEAD: A series of major and minor disputes have sent relations between the United States and India skidding to the lowest level since Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi took office in 1984, American and Indian officials said today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Aloha Inc., Honolulu, parent of Aloha Airlines, named Sheridan C. F. Ing chairman of both the parent company and the airline. He succeeds Dr. Hung Wo Ching.

headline: Schwab Group Completes Buyout
abstract: LEAD: The purchase of Charles Schwab & Com pany, the discount brokerage, from the BankAmerica Corporation has been completed by the CL Acquisition Corporation, a company formed by investors led by Charles R. Schwab, senior management and employees through a profit-sharing plan. The $280 million price is being financed by a syndicate of seven banks led by the Security Pacific National

headline: London Stocks Decline
abstract: LEAD: Stocks continued their selloff today because of disappointment that overseas buyers have yet to enter the British market in a big way after last week's Conservative Party general election victory, dealers said. The Financial Times index of 100 shares closed down 27.1 points, at 2,266.1.

headline: THE HIGH-TECH AUCTION IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: THE scene was more reminiscent of a professional seminar than a sale. Men in pin-striped suits took turns at the podium and pointed to slides that flashed by on a screen. But the 1,600 people packed into the conference room at the Dedham, Mass., Holiday Inn recently were bargain hunting in cast-off computers.

headline: Star Broker Gets 15 Years
abstract: LEAD: Leslie Roberts, who dropped out of college and became a top broker for E.F. Hutton & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company, has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for defrauding his uncle of millions of dollars.

headline: SCATTERED GAINS FOR EXPORTERS
abstract: LEAD: A variety of companies around the nation are finally reporting an upturn in their exports.

headline: Continental's Decision On Ogden Stirs Rumors
abstract: LEAD: The surprise announcement last Thursday that William S. Ogden, the No. 2 man at the Continental Illinois Corporation would not succeed John E. Swearingen as chairman, is expected to result in the departure of several executives in the Ogden camp, according to bank officials who requested anonymity.

headline: Bonn Decision to Try T.W.A. Suspect Is Seen
abstract: LEAD: The West German Government is expected to announce this week that it will try a man suspected of hijacking a Trans World Airlines jetliner and not extradite him to the United States, according to reports in West German newspapers.

headline: New Zealand Enacts Ban on Nuclear Ships
abstract: LEAD: Parliament approved legislation Thursday banning nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships from New Zealand's ports, putting into law a policy that the Labor Government adopted nearly three years ago.

headline: U.S. INVESTIGATORS TO TALK TO IRAQI PILOT
abstract: LEAD: Iraq will allow a team of American investigators to interview the Iraqi pilot whose warplane attacked the frigate Stark and the Iraqi military officers who ordered the mission, American officials said today.

headline: CHURCH'S CHIEF FIGHTS FORMER COLLEAGUE'S BID
abstract: LEAD: J. David Bamberger left Ohio for the Southwest in the 1950's to seek his fortune. He found it, first in vacuum cleaners, then in fried chicken.

headline: U.S. DROPS ITS CASE AGAINST A MARINE IN EMBASSY SPYING
abstract: LEAD: Charges were dropped today against a second Marine guard accused of spying at the United States Embassy in Moscow. The move amounted to an acknowledgment that the Government could not prove that a crippling security breach occurred at the embassy.

headline: Resorts Rejects $220 Million Offer
abstract: LEAD: Resorts International Inc., the casino-hotel operator, said today that its board had rejected the $220 million takeover offer from a group led by Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman and investor. Separately, Mr. Davis offered $348 million for Spectradyne Inc., the leading supplier of pay-per-view movie systems to hotels.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * British Telecommunications, London, announced the creation of British Telecom Inc. as its American subsidiary.

headline: Non-Oil Goods Aid Iran
abstract: LEAD: Iran has earned $2.35 billion in the last five years from selling agricultural items, carpets and other non-oil exports, a customs report said today. The report, quoted by the national press agency, said exports of hand-woven Persian carpets doubled in the 1986-87 fiscal year, which ended March 20.

headline: Stern Walters Is Sold To Managers by Bates
abstract: LEAD: The top management of Stern Walters/Earle Lundgin, Chicago, has bought the $30 million agency back from Ted Bates Worldwide, which acquired it in 1978. Since last summer Bates has been a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi of London. Terms of the buyback were not disclosed.

headline: Valuation Table Could Change
abstract: LEAD: ACCOUNTANTS and lawyers are buzzing these days about the possibility of a change in the Internal Revenue Service valuation tables that are central in calculating annuities, trusts and other asset-transfer devices.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Kenneth Hite has joined Korey, Kay & Partners as senior vice president, account director.

headline: ANOTHER BLOW FOR HAITI: A SUGAR MILL CLOSES
abstract: LEAD: A sugar mill that was Haiti's second largest employer has shut down, saying it was put out of business by sugar smuggled from Miami and the Dominican Republic.

headline: Official Resigns At the Garden
abstract: LEAD: Gulf and Western Inc. said yesterday that Allan R. Fields had resigned as executive vice president and chief operating officer of its Madison Square Garden Corporation subsidiary.

headline: PERES'S STAFF, IN ISRAELI INFIGHTING, BARS SHAMIR MESSAGE TO EMBASSIES
abstract: LEAD: The fighting inside the Israeli Government reached a new level today.

headline: Home Group Adding Gruntal
abstract: LEAD: As expected, the Home Group, parent of the Home Insurance Company, yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the Gruntal Financial Corporation, parent of Gruntal & Company, for about $145 million. Home is a major property and casualty insurer, while Gruntal is an East Coast regional brokerage firm.

headline: Dow Climbs 0.78 Point, to 2,408.13
abstract: LEAD: The stock market moved tentatively higher yesterday in trading enlivened by Wall Street's apprehension over today's ''triple-witching hour'' and by real or rumored takeover action.

headline: The Head of Caremark Is a Pioneer in His Field
abstract: LEAD: In the late 1970's, James M. Sweeney realized that a considerable number of hospital patients requiring intravenous therapy and nutrition did not really need to be hospitalized. Parenteral, or nondigestive, feeding could be done at home, he reasoned, freeing patients and their insurers from uncomfortable, expensive hospital stays.

headline: Dow Up 16.39; Volume Still Modest
abstract: LEAD: Building on the previous day's sharp rally, the Dow Jones industrial average added 16.39 points yesterday, to close at 2,337.08, its highest level in a month.

headline: Economic Scene; Responding To Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: DOES the drive of General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev to ''reconstruct'' the Soviet economy and society provide an opportunity for the United States to strengthen its own economy and stabilize the international system, of which it is the leader?

headline: FLORIDA BANK MERGER
abstract: LEAD: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. and Home Federal Bank of Florida said they had signed an agreement calling for the conversion of Home Federal to a state-chartered savings and loan and then to a bank, and for its subsequent merger with the Barnett Bank of Pinellas County, a Barnett Banks subsidiary.

headline: 5.3% Heck's Stake
abstract: LEAD: Two investors told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had acquired 469,900 shares of Heck's Inc., or 5.3 percent of the outstanding common stock. Monroe Milstein, president of Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse in Burlington, N.J., and Andrew Milstein, a White Plains lawyer, said they had bought the stake for $2.1 million for investment purposes.

headline: GOING AFTER THE INDISCRIMINATE SPENDER
abstract: LEAD: AS POPULAR as exotic fruits have become, they are still small potatoes at many supermarket cash registers. Mr. Kemp of Super Valu, for example, says they account for just 1 percent of total fruit sales at his stores.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a motion-picture exhibitor, said it and a private investor had agreed to buy almost 6.3 million common shares of TPI Enterprises Inc. that are held by Rank America Inc. at $6 a share. The name of the investor was not disclosed.

headline: NO REAGAN FRAUD, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
abstract: LEAD: The White House asserted today that President Reagan did not take part in the criminal conspiracy to defraud the Government and support the Nicaraguan rebels that was headed by Carl R. Channell, a conservative fund-raiser who pleaded guilty to a felony count on Wednesday.

headline: Borg Agrees to Give GAF Information
abstract: LEAD: After extensive negotiations, the Borg-Warner Corporation agreed yesterday to turn over confidential information about itself to the GAF Corporation as part of what could be a new takeover bid by GAF for the Chicago-based industrial company.

headline: Morgan Plans Drug Testing
abstract: LEAD: Morgan Stanley & Company, one of Wall Street's largest and more prestigious investment banks, will announce today a new policy of mandatory drug testing for all existing as well as incoming employees worldwide, officials at the company said yesterday.

headline: MAXWELL'S SUCCESS IS UNCERTAIN
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street professionals said yesterday that there were numerous possible outcomes to Robert Maxwell's takeover bid for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., a leading publishing company.

headline: Clabir to Buy Hi-Shear
abstract: LEAD: The Clabir Corporation said yesterday that its subsidiary, the General Defense Corporation, would acquire Hi-Shear Industries for $140 million, or $23.50 a share.

headline: Lockheed Stock Soars on Rumors
abstract: LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation's stock jumped sharply today in heavy trading. Wall Street analysts said there was speculation that the General Electric Company, the Ford Motor Company or the Chrysler Corporation would make a bid to acquire Lockheed, a major military and aerospace contractor. All four companies declined to comment.

abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Avnet Inc. is offering $100 million of A-2/A+ rated 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 at a price of 100 through Dillon, Read. Noncallable for 2 years, the debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $43 a share.

abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: LAWSUITS, AND WORRY, MOUNT OVER BIC LIGHTER
abstract: LEAD: The Bic Corporation is facing mounting lawsuits on behalf of people who have been burned - and in some cases killed - by fires they say were caused by defects in the company's disposable butane lighters.

headline: Interest Rates Little Changed
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates were stable yesterday as the credit markets were beset with uncertainty about the future of the dollar and the American economy.

headline: TESTIMONY REVEALS DIFFERING VIEWS OF CURBS ON CONTRA AID
abstract: LEAD: Testimony in the Iran-contra hearings this week shows that Administration officials held sharply differing views about what the laws restricting aid to the contras permitted them to do.

headline: GORBACHEV IS CRITICAL OF ICBM'S
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, accused the United States today of adopting negotiating stances on intercontinental nuclear weapons that would harm Soviet security.

headline: Message From the Sponsor
abstract: LEAD: The White House asked a Nashville radio station today to refrain from using a tape of President Reagan saying he listens to ''WSM, the 50,000-watt blowtorch of the South.''

headline: WHERE THE HIGH YEN HURTS
abstract: LEAD: In the early 1980's, many American manufacturers, reeling under competitive pressures, cut back their production in the United States and began importing components, even entire products, from Japan.

headline: Key Agriculture Official Leaving Reagan Ranks
abstract: LEAD: Daniel G. Amstutz, who played a pivotal role in shaping the Reagan Administration's farm program and in efforts to reduce global agricultural trade friction, is resigning as Under Secretary of Agriculture for international affairs and commodity programs.

headline: Exocet Missile: Echo of Falklands
abstract: LEAD: The French-made Exocet missile is Iraq's weapon of choice for air-launched attacks on shipping in the Persian Gulf. It is a sea-skimming weapon that achieved notoriety in the Falkland War, when Argentina used an Exocet to sink the British destroyer Sheffield.

headline: Candidates of Aquino Lead Philippine Vote
abstract: LEAD: Candidates supporting President Corazon C. Aquino took a strong early lead today in the first unofficial returns from Monday's vote for a new Senate.

headline: Toyota Studies Europe Production
abstract: LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, said it was studying the possibility of producing vehicles in Europe. Asahi Shimbun, a nationally circulated newspaper, had reported that Toyota and Volkswagenwerk A.G. of West Germany planned to produce about 5,000 commercial vehicles a month next year at an idle VW plant in

headline: Several Major Questions Still Unanswered, Including What President Knew and Did
abstract: LEAD: With the end of the first stage of the Congressional investigation today, one crucial question about the Iran-contra affair and several other important ones remain unanswered.

headline: PHILIPS SEES OIL PRICE RISE
abstract: LEAD: The Phillips Petroleum Company's chairman, C.J. Silas, said that oil prices, which fell sharply last year, should gradually increase in 1987. ''We expect oil prices to continue an upward trend, but the improvement will be gradual - and will probably be somewhat erratic during the second and third quarters,'' Mr.

headline: Firebomber Attacks Dutch Chief's Home
abstract: LEAD: A firebomb was thrown through a window of Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers's home on Wednesday night, but the Prime Minister threw it back into the street, the police said today.

headline: The Problems Go Far Beyond Chips
abstract: LEAD: AMERICANS have been spoiling for a fight with Japan over trade issues. They tend to see their nation as a Gary Cooper or a John Wayne character: well-intentioned and wanting to be fair, but willing to throw a few punches if necessary. Japanese attitudes are hardening as well. As Kazuo Nukazawa, an official of Keidanren, a powerful business association, said: ''Japan has become a big boy, so it shouldn't be kicked around by the teacher.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 8, 1987
abstract: LEAD: MARKETS  A surge of Japanese orders lifted bond prices and created hopes that the trend toward higher interest rates had been thwarted for now. The buying of 30-year Treasury bonds by Japanese securities firms soothed fears that turmoil in the foreign exchange market and trade disputes between Tokyo and Washington would interrupt the flow of Japanese capital into the American bond market.

headline: Municipals Retain Allure
abstract: LEAD: DURING the debate over tax revision last year, some people worried that municipal bonds would become much less popular because of the lowering of personal tax rates. But since the passage of the new tax law, municipals have continued to be a widely used alternative for many individuals who still find themselves in maximum combined

headline: Kaisertech Ltd.
abstract: LEAD: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that it had completed its reorganization into a holding company called Kaisertech Ltd., with its largest stockholder, the British investor Alan Clore, as chairman. Holders of Kaiser Aluminum stock automatically have become holders of the new company, and Kaiser Aluminum will continue as the operating company with current management in place.

headline: Water Bonds Issued in Texas
abstract: LEAD: The Coastal Water Authority of Texas is offering $120 million of water revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for an issue due in 2006 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: U.S. WARSHIPS TO SET SAIL FOR GULF DUTY
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon said today that a fleet of Navy ships, including three vessels bound for the Persian Gulf, would sail from East Coast ports on Friday and Saturday.

headline: COMPUTER CHAIN SALE ANNOUNCED
abstract: LEAD: Capping a year of speculation and rumors, the Computerland Corporation, the world's largest personal computer retailer, said today that an investment group led by E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Company had agreed to acquire the company.

headline: Associates' Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Associates Corporation of North America is offering $100 million of 8 3/8 percent senior notes due in 1990 through underwriters led by U.B.S. Securities. The price may vary, the underwriters said, though the notes were offered at 99.923 to yield 8.40 percent. Rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P., they yield about four-tenths of a point more than Treasury issues of similar maturity.

headline: Asian Growth Averages 6%
abstract: LEAD: The economies of 17 Asian members of the Asian Development Bank grew an average of 6 percent in 1986, the same as in 1985, the bank's annual report said.

headline: Pretoria Ousting 2 Reporters for British TV
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government today ordered two senior British television correspondents to leave the country.

headline: Goodrich Shows Profit
abstract: LEAD: The B. F. Goodrich Company reported today first-quarter net income of $3.8 million, or 6 cents a share, reversing the $20.7 million loss it recorded in the first quarter of 1986.

headline: GUIDING A LOW-PROFILE AGENCY THROUGH A HIGH-TECH STORM
abstract: LEAD: WHILE its archives are filled with the names of visionary inventors like Edison and Bell, the United States Patent and Trademark Office is itself a paper-shuffling bureaucracy - one that ought to be the safest place imaginable for a Government functionary.

headline: THE ROAD TO A VIOLENT DEATH: VICTIM SOUGHT 'SOCIAL IMPACT'
abstract: LEAD: The American volunteer who was reported killed by Nicaraguan rebels was described by friends as a political activist interested in Central American causes.

headline: Disney Project Given Approval
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company has received approval from the Burbank, Calif., City Council to begin developing a theme park, studio attraction, hotel and shopping mall project on a 40-acre redevelopment site in the city's central district. The project, called Disney-

headline: AN AMMONIA LEAK SPREADS PANIC IN BHOPAL
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of residents of Bhopal fled their homes in panic early Tuesday morning when ammonia gas leaked from a factory near the Union Carbide pesticide plant there, Indian news agencies reported this morning.

headline: Chief Adds a Post In Gulf States Shift
abstract: LEAD: E. Linn Draper, president, chief executive and vice chairman of the Gulf States Utilities Company, has been named to the additional post of chairman, according to a company announcement.
