headline: Texas Instruments
abstract: LEAD: Sweden's telecommunications giant L. M. Ericsson said it had signed an agreement with Texas Instruments Inc. Under the deal, Texas Instruments will design and produce semiconductors for use by Ericsson. In return Texas Instruments is to receive more business from Ericsson. No financial transactions are involved, Ericsson said.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: LEAD: ''We're going to have the next election under a new constitution. An important share of the party shares this view.''

headline: Theater Group Leader From Ethiopia Defects
abstract: LEAD: The theater manager for an Ethiopian folkloric group said today that he had defected to the United States because he could no longer function in a country where all artistic endeavors are controlled by the state.

headline: ATHENS LINKS BASES TO TURKEY ISSUE
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has proposed that negotiations on the continued presence of United States military bases in Greece be linked to this country's long-running dispute with Turkey and that any accord with Washington be put to a referendum.

headline: SHAKE-UP AT MERRILL EXPANDS
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday a high-level shake-up in the management of its securities trading in an effort to recover from last month's loss of $250 million in its mortgage-bond trading.

headline: Hutton Studying Aide's Role
abstract: LEAD: E. F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that a senior executive has taken a leave of absence pending a review of his role in several international transactions in which Hutton received and transferred millions of dollars for a Swiss citizen who was reportedly laundering money for narcotics dealers.

headline: MODEST PRICE INCREASES EXPECTED FOR GASOLINE
abstract: LEAD: Supplies of crude oil and gasoline are plentiful, but retail gasoline prices will probably increase modestly during the Memorial Day weekend and through mid-June, according to oil industry experts and motorists groups.

headline: Republic-Interfirst Merger Approved
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board approved an application by the Republicbank Corporation to acquire the Interfirst Corporation, creating a $28 billion banking concern that would be the largest in Texas. Republic and Interfirst, which are both based in Dallas, are currently the second- and third-largest banking organizations in Texas, with $14.4 billion and $13.6 billion in domestic deposits, respectively.

headline: COVERT OPERATIONS CHANGES URGED
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will be urged to consolidate some of the Administration's covert operations overseas and to end others that are considered outdated, a White House official said today.

headline: AMR's Profits Increase 44.2%
abstract: LEAD: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 44.2 percent, to $19.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from $13.8 million, or 20 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues increased 3.4 percent, to $1.51 billion, from $1.46 billion.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Challenger International Ltd., Hamilton, Bermuda, which is involved in petroleum products and crude oil marketing, appointed Jeffrey W. Hobbing president and managing director. Mr. Hobbing, who will also continue as president of Challenger Petroleum U.S.A. Inc., succeeds Anthony P. Towell, who resigned to pursue other interests.

headline: Swiss Accept Yamani
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia's former oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, has received permission to reside in the village of Chermignon, near the ski resort of Crans-Montana, Swiss officials said today. A spokesman for the Justice Ministry said the authorities in Bern had ''agreed in principle'' to a request for a permit Sheik Yamani made in February.

headline: JAPAN PUSHES STIMULUS PLAN
abstract: LEAD: In announcing its latest measures to stimulate the economy and promote imports, the Japanese Government appealed to its trading partners today to trust that this time its program would produce results.

headline: Burlington Bid Rise Hinted by Edelman
abstract: LEAD: Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. hinted yesterday in a letter written to Burlington Industries that they might raise their joint bid for the company from $77 a share.

headline: Purchase by G.E. Credit
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Credit Corporation said it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy all the capital stock of the D and K Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of Kraft Inc. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. D and K, with assets of more than $1 billion, is involved in the leasing of automobile fleets.

headline: CRISIS IS UNSETTLED DESPITE OVERTURES OFFERED IN SEOUL
abstract: LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan was reported today to have made important concessions to the opposition, but critical details remained vague, leaving the country's political crisis still unsettled.

headline: CITIBANK RAISES ITS PRIME RATE
abstract: LEAD: Citibank raised its prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent yesterday, the first increase by a major bank since June 1984.

headline: Advertising; Geer, DuBois Rewarded With B. Dalton Account
abstract: LEAD: Geer, DuBois has been rewarded for its good work on the relatively small Barnes & Noble bookstores account, billing in the $1 million class. It has been given the $9 million account of the B. Dalton chain of bookstores.

headline: WHT'S NEW IN FOREIGN LANGUAGE TELEVISION
abstract: LEAD: ROBERT HITCHENS, until recently a salesman for the Spanish International Network in New York, used to find selling advertising on Spanish-language programs a thankless task. ''We kidded about the orders we got: Get out, stay out, don't come back,'' he recalled.

headline: Bankers Trust Deposit Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 7 percent deposit notes due in 1989 at a price of par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: IT'S TIME TO CONSIDER A KEOGH - FOR '87
abstract: LEAD: IF you are a self-employed professional, or a homemaker or salaried worker with a sideline business, a Keogh plan is one of the most attractive ways to accumulate money for retirement. Similar in concept to a corporate retirement or profit-sharing plan, a Keogh plan allows you to make tax-deductible annual contributions to it, and the earnings accumulate tax-free until they are withdrawn at retirement.

headline: Air Force Halts Money to Northrop
abstract: LEAD: The Air Force has suspended $25 million in monthly payments to the Northrop Corporation for work on a guidance system for the MX missile. The action came in a dispute concerning late deliveries of an electronic system, known as inertial measurement units, according to Maj. Barry Glickman, an Air Force spokesman.

headline: Borg-Warner Chief Resigns
abstract: LEAD: The Borg-Warner Corporation, the diversified manufacturer that was recently sold to Merrill Lynch Capital Partners for $4 billion, said today that its chief executive, Clarence E. Johnson, had resigned. Borg-Warner said that

headline: GORBACHEV POLICY GAINS AS 3 ALLIES ADVANCE IN PARTY
abstract: LEAD: In a major show of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political strength, his contentious plan for restructuring the economy won formal backing today from the Communist Party's Central Committee.

headline: 2 LEBANESE FREED BUT AMERICAN IS HELD
abstract: LEAD: Two Lebanese nationals kidnapped here a week ago with an American journalist were released today, but the journalist, Charles Glass, remained missing.

headline: SOUTH KOREA STEPS UP ITS ATTACKS ON OPPOSITION
abstract: LEAD: The Government stepped up its attacks today on South Korea's two leading opposition figures, blaming them for the suspension of constitutional debate ordered earlier in the day by President Chun Doo Hwan.

headline: Egypt Rebukes P.L.O.
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid announcing in Cairo the closing of Palestine Liberation Organization offices in Egypt. Page A12. (Reuters)

headline: SOUTH AFRICA BARS PROTESTS BACKING DETAINEE FREEDOM
abstract: LEAD: South Africa tightened its 10-month-old state of emergency today by putting into effect a law forbidding any protests on behalf of political detainees.

headline: British Offering Oversubscribed
abstract: LEAD: The British Government will offer private investors some of the shares of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the airplane engine maker, originally allotted for institutional investors, because of an oversubscription of the public offering, the Government's adviser said. The Government is offering a total of 801.5 million shares in Rolls-Royce for $:1.36 billion, about $2.3 billion at current exchange rates, or 170 pence - $2.86 - a share.

headline: Israeli Arabs Stage a Strike, Charging Unequal Treatment
abstract: LEAD: Israeli Arabs staged a general strike today to protest what they call Government discrimination against the 700,000 Arabs who hold Israeli citizenship.

headline: Fallon, McElligott Gets Squirtco as New Client
abstract: LEAD: Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis, continuing to roll, has filled the soft drink niche. The client is Squirtco of Holland, Mich. The assignment is for Squirt and Diet Squirt Plus.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SEOUL PARTY CHIEF
abstract: LEAD: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from a nationally broadcast address today by Roh Tae Woo, chairman of the governing Democratic Justice Party, proposing sweeping constitutional changes:

headline: CAPS AND GOWNS AND 3-PIECE SUITS
abstract: LEAD: AGRICULTURE has always been a big deal in Arkansas.

headline: GLOOMIER ECONOMIC OUTLOOK
abstract: LEAD: The West's central bankers, in a gloomy economic report, say that the industrial countries would have a hard time reducing trade imbalances without disrupting financial markets, causing inflation in the United States or pushing the United States or other countries into recession.

headline: SECORD'S LAST DAY: HARD QUESTIONS AND AN UNUSUAL PROPOSAL
abstract: LEAD: Richard V. Secord made his last scheduled appearance yesterday before a Congressional hearing in Washington, testifying on covert operations in the Iran-contra affair. Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, is scheduled as the next witness when the hearings resume Monday.

headline: EX-C.I.A. OFFICIAL MAY LINK SECORD TO DISLOYAL AGENT
abstract: LEAD: A retired C.I.A. official is expected to tell Congress next week of a financial link between Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a key figure in the Iran-contra affair, and Edwin P. Wilson, the renegade C.I.A. agent convicted of smuggling arms to Libya, according to Congressional investigators.

headline: Ex-Bank Official in Shift
abstract: LEAD: Thomas A. Cooper, who resigned as president of the BankAmerica Corporation last month, is expected to be named the chief executive of the ISFA Corporation, a Tampa, Fla., company that operates stock brokerage and insurance sales programs for banks and thrift institutions, according to a banking industry source.

headline: Sainsbury in Pact For 74% of Shaw's
abstract: LEAD: J Sainsbury P.L.C. said it had an agreement that would allow it to increase its stake in Shaw's Supermarkets Inc. to 74 percent. The British supermarket chain also said it had already raised its stake in the New England company to 49.4 percent.

headline: Lord & Taylor President Comes From Within
abstract: LEAD: Frank C. Watson has been named president of Lord & Taylor, the retail fashion chain, its parent, the May Department Stores Company, announced yesterday.

headline: GLITTER AT HANDY & HARMON
abstract: LEAD: The strength in precious metals has brought sharp run-ups in mining stocks, many of which have doubled since the first of the year. But the shares of the metals refiners have not been quite so buoyant. Handy & Harman, a leading fabricator of gold and silver, has risen only about a third since January, to around $26 a share last week.

headline: Market Place; Bonds Finding Support Again
abstract: LEAD: PLUMMETING bond prices rattled investor nerves for much of April and May. But now that the dollar has stabilized somewhat and bonds have recouped part of their losses, some brokerage firms are taking a more favorable view of fixed-income securities.

headline: INDUSTRY BACKS EASING OF JAPAN CURBS
abstract: LEAD: Electronics industry executives expressed support today for President Reagan's decision to remove some trade sanctions against Japan, but they said the action would have little effect on American consumers.

headline: ARGENTINE CRISIS IGNITES PRESS DISPUTE
abstract: LEAD: Argentina's recent military crisis set off a conflict between the Government of President Raul Alfonsin and the privately owned press over coverage and the way the Government used television to rally support.

headline: Soviet Prices: Strawberries Are a Model
abstract: LEAD: At the Central Market today, a vendor sat behind an assortment of choice strawberries, telling the few inquiring shoppers that the berries cost the equivalent of $5.50 a pound. There were few buyers, and no line.

headline: Advertising; Fairchild Bringing Out A Weekly on Travel
abstract: LEAD: Fairchild Publications, publisher of Women's Wear Daily and other trade papers and magazines, got into consumer magazine publishing in 1971 and is now preparing to add a fourth title in that sector on Oct. 5.

headline: ILLEGAL SALE SPURS OSLO CRACKDOWN
abstract: LEAD: Norway's Defense Minister said today that his Government was taking steps to reorganize a major state-owned company and tighten export controls in the wake of disclosures that the company had illegally sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union.

headline: NOW, TAX REVISION IN SWEDEN
abstract: LEAD: The global push for cutting tax rates, spanning ideological boundaries, has come even to Sweden, home of the world's highest taxes.

headline: Chrysler to Extend Talks With A.M.C.
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and Renault said they had agreed to extend by up to two weeks their talks on reaching definitive agreement on Chrysler's proposed $1.5 billion takeover of the American Motors Corporation. Chrysler and Renualt, the French-owned car maker, said in a statement that they ''now plan to complete work by April 23.

headline: SOVIET MISSILE PROPOSALS PUT KOHL IN A TOUGH SPOT
abstract: LEAD: In trying to fashion a coherent response to Soviet proposals for the abolition of medium- and shorter-range missiles in Europe, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has stumbled into one of the most politically painful passages of his five and a half years in office.

headline: Cannon Plans Refinancing
abstract: LEAD: The Cannon Group said today that a group including its founders was preparing a financial restructuring plan for the troubled independent film production company.

headline: SHIFTS URGED IN BANK LAWS
abstract: LEAD: Robert Heller, a Federal Reserve Board governor, called for broad deregulation of the American banking industry today, saying it would increase American competitiveness in international markets.

headline: Comex to Cut Hours Monday
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Exchange, the largest gold and silver futures market, announced late yesterday that it would drastically shorten its trading hours on Monday to clear the paperwork resulting from this week's hectic activity. Last week, trading in

headline: Baltimore Utility Marketing Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company is offering $100 million of 8 1/2 percent bonds due in 1997 at a price of 98.419 to yield 8.74 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: MULRONEY AWAITS VISIT BY PRESIDENT
abstract: LEAD: When President Reagan arrives here Sunday for a two-day visit he will find his host, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, more careworn than the last time Mr. Reagan was in Canada.

headline: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
abstract: LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 17, 1987:           MONDAY        Conn. Natural Gas   NAFCO Fin. Group        Detroit Edison   Tyco Labs        Kay Jewelers   United Illuminating        NWA Inc.        TUESDAY        Briggs & Stratton   Longs Drug Stores        Coleman Co.   Mich. Energy Resources        Foote, Cone & Beld.

headline: NEW U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW IS SAID TO HAVE WIRETAPS
abstract: LEAD: Some members of Congress and intelligence officials say they believe that a new United States Embassy building under construction in Moscow is contaminated with Soviet eavesdropping devices and that the entire $190 million project should be scrapped.

headline: Bonn Expectations Revive for a Visit by Honecker
abstract: LEAD: Some recent comments by the East German leader, Erich Honecker, have again raised politically charged expectations that he will finally make his often-postponed visit to West Germany.

headline: Gunman Kills 7 in Belgium
abstract: LEAD: A gunman killed seven people, including a child and five members of one family, before being found dead in his car today. The police said the man, found near the southern town of Mons, apparently shot himself. They gave no further details. The man shot dead five members of a family and wounded a sixth person at a farm in Pepingen.

headline: PUTTING A STOP TO RAPID CURRENCY SWINGS
abstract: LEAD: JUST about everyone is dissatisfied with the wildly fluctuating currency values - euphemistically called ''floating'' or ''flexible'' exchange rates - that characterize today's international monetary system. Without a common monetary standard, under which exchange rates could be stabilized, the remarkable economic integration of Western Europe, North America and East Asia in both commodity trade and financial flows has become less efficient, and is becoming untenable.

headline: Halliburton Posts Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Halliburton Company said today that it had a loss of $8.2 million on sharply lower revenues in the first quarter because of continued weak demand in its energy-related businesses. In the first quarter of 1986, before the dramatic decline in oil prices, Halliburton posted an $11.2 million profit.

headline: Singapore Is Holding 12 in 'Marxist Conspiracy'
abstract: LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew today detained without trial 12 people it accuses of involvement in a ''Marxist conspiracy to subvert the existing social and political system.''

headline: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS JOIN STRIKE
abstract: LEAD: Lebanese Christians joined today in a general strike called by Moslem leaders to protest the assassination of Prime Minister Rashid Karami.

headline: 5 Senators Offer Legislation To Shut P.L.O. Offices in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Bob Dole and four other Senators proposed legislation today to close the two Palestine Liberation Organization offices in the United States.

headline: Bidders Seen On Thrift Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company and a group headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, are among five bidders for the troubled Financial Corporation of America, an industry publication reported Friday.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Michelle Sonken promoted to publisher at Avenue magazine.

headline: BOTHA OUTLINES TERMS FOR ANY CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha, opening the segregated Parliament, asserted today that there would be no further political initiatives until black leaders were prepared to enter talks on power-sharing on the Government's terms.

headline: MARKETS FAIL TO DEVELOP FOR THIRD-WORLD DEBT
abstract: LEAD: A promising technique for dealing with the third-world debt crisis - the exchange of bank loans for ownership in companies in developing nations -still faces many obstacles two years after being hailed as a breakthrough. And another logical outgrowth, a speculative market in the deeply discounted debt of third-world borrowers, is going nowhere.

headline: New Wrinkles In Unit Trusts
abstract: LEAD: THE combination of higher interest rates and a wider choice of portfolios has drawn new business to unit investment trusts.

headline: 'De-Powering'
abstract: LEAD:  To the Editor:

headline: SALOMAN CITES STAKE BY HARCOURT
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed yesterday that it held Harcourt Brace Jovanovich debentures that it said are convertible into almost 22 million shares of the publishing company's common shares.

headline: PRESIDENT CRITICIZES TRADE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan warned today that a restrictive amendment to trade legislation being debated on Capitol Hill this week was a dangerous proposal. He said it could disrupt the world trading system and jeopardize relations with some of America's major trading partners.

headline: China to Issue Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of China will issue about $135 million in yuan-denominated bonds on Tuesday, the first domestically issued bonds from the Communist Government, the official New China News Agency has reported. The one-year bonds will be issued in denominations of 100 yuan, about $27, and 500 yuan, about $135, and will have an annual interest rate of 9 percent, the agency said.

headline: PERU DURG DEALERS KILL 6 OFFICERS
abstract: LEAD: Cocaine traffickers, firing automatic rifles and hurling grenades, killed six police officers and wounded six others in a predawn attack Monday on a police post in Peru's coca-growing jungle region, the Government said today.

headline: PRODUCTIVITY GAIN SHOWN BY BUSINESS
abstract: LEAD: The productivity of American business, an indicator that has assumed new urgency in the debate over the nation's ability to meet world competition, rose at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today.

headline: Shamrock to Sell Coal Subsidiary
abstract: LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said that it had once again agreed to sell its coal subsidiary to the Arch Mineral Corporation for $135 million. The two companies had reached a similar agreement last July regarding the Diamond Shamrock Coal Company, but in October Diamond Shamrock said they canceled the deal because they ''were unable to reach mutually acceptable terms.

headline: PISA IS HOPIN TO GIVE LEANING TOWER A REST
abstract: LEAD: ''The problem is no one really knows why this tower doesn't fall,'' said Giuseppe Toniolo, the tower's white-haired keeper, gazing at it through finely traced Gothic windows. ''From an engineering point of view, it's an enigma.''

headline: New Computer Series by NCR
abstract: LEAD: The NCR Corporation will announce a new series of personal computers today, in one of the first major responses to the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal System/2.

headline: THE POPE IN POLAND: A LIFT FOR SOLIDARITY'S SPIRIT
abstract: LEAD: During his week in Poland, Pope John Paul II grew steadily bolder as he challenged the Government to prove its assertions of reform, pressed priests to identify with the aspirations of Solidarity, and urged society to persist in patient pursuit of liberty.

headline: Credit Needs Of Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's new Finance Minister has estimated that the country will need new credit to cover about 50 percent of future interest payments as part of any agreement leading to a lifting of its moratorium on some of its debt payments, according to Government officials.

headline: Ex-Officer of Pepsico Is Cogenic Chairman
abstract: LEAD: When Herman A. Schaefer retired two years ago as chief financial officer of Pepsico Inc., he planned to get involved in a few ventures and take life a little easier.

headline: Market Place; Analyst Lists Bearish Signals
abstract: LEAD: SINCE the Dow Jones industrial average has sailed past five ''century'' marks already this year, it is no wonder that Wall Street analysts keep lifting their market expectations. Byron R. Wien, domestic equity strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, is no exception.

headline: INVESTIGATORS SAY GROUP RAISED $2 MILLION FOR CONTRA ARMS AID
abstract: LEAD: A conservative, tax-exempt organization raised at least $2.28 million in an operation that Congressional investigators say was apparently intended to buy arms for the Nicaraguan rebels. The group says the funds were used to buy Christmas gifts for the rebels' children.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: LEAD: An article last Sunday about the resignation of the White House's executive chef, Henry Haller, misidentified his wife. She is Carole Itjen.

headline: Builder's Stake In French TV
abstract: LEAD: A consortium headed by the construction group Bouygues S.A. has been awarded a 50 percent controlling stake in France's oldest and most widely watched television network, the Government-owned Television Francaise-1.

headline: Ford-Nissan Study
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company and Japan's Nissan Motor Company said they are planning for the first time to study the feasibility of developing and producing a vehicle together in North America. The two auto makers said that if such a vehicle were developed, it would not compete with any of the companies' existing models.

headline: Victory at Hand, Aquino's Backers Split Up
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino's backers, apparently headed for solid control of the Senate and the House of Representatives, have begun to fragment into competing camps in the race for legislative leadership.

headline: Officer Quits Calvin Klein
abstract: LEAD: Calvin Klein Industries has lost its second high-ranking executive this week. Edward M. Jones 3d has resigned as president and director of international licensing at the company's Classics division, the fashion designer Calvin Klein said yesterday.

headline: U.S. CALLS HALT TO INVESTIGATION OF A CONTRACTOR
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department said today that it was closing its three-year fraud inquiry into the General Dynamics Corporation because there was insufficient evidence to obtain a successful prosecution.

headline: Libya Releases a Scot Held 5 Years in Spying
abstract: LEAD: A Scottish engineer given a 12-year jail sentence in Libya in 1982 for ''economic espionage'' has been released and plans to return home soon, the Foreign Office said today.

headline: Marshall Plan
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. WORKERS STAY IN LIBYA DESPITE BAN
abstract: LEAD: An American oil executive, sitting in an office decorated with a portrait of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said he enjoyed doing business here and had no qualms about violating President Reagan's order banning Americans from working in Libya.

headline: MORE TOSHIBA TOOLS SAID TO REACH SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: Federal officials said yesterday that they now believe that the Toshiba Machine Company sent a second illegal shipment of four giant propeller milling machines to the Soviet Union in April and May 1984.

headline: GOODYEAR POSTS PROFIT AFTER LOSS IN '86 QUARTER
abstract: LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which sold most of its non-tire businesses last year to thwart a takeover attempt, yesterday reported a first-quarter profit of $284.2 million, compared with a loss of $212.7 million in the period a year ago.

headline: Trade Surplus Hits $101 Billion in Japan
abstract: LEAD: In the face of heightened trade tensions with the United States, Japan reported its largest-ever trade surplus, $101.4 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31.

headline: U.S. UNCERTAIN ON OZONE PACT
abstract: LEAD: The United States may back away from a tentative international agreement to freeze and ultimately reduce production and consumption of chemicals believed to deplete the earth's protective covering of ozone, Administration officials said today.

headline: AUSTRIAN REBUFFED BY U.S. IN PLEA FOR WALDHEIM
abstract: LEAD: The Austrian Chancellor was rebuffed first by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and then by President Reagan today when he asked for a modification of the ruling barring President Kurt Waldheim from entering the United States.

headline: Patents; Radiator Reduces Heat On Orbiting Satellites
abstract: LEAD: A thermal radiator for orbiting satellites, such as those that relay television broadcasts from one earth station to another, has been invented by James F. Dalby, an engineer in Reston, Va. It is designed to reduce the heat generated by electronic equipment.

headline: Major Acquisition By G.E. Possible
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., said the giant manufacturing and services concern would make another major acquisition if it found a target as attractive as the RCA Corporation, which was bought last year. ''Acquisition is clearly an acceptable route toward accelerated growth and, should another opportunity of the quality of the RCA merger present itself, we will move decisively,'' Mr.

headline: EX-GUINNESS CHAIRMAN ACCUSED ON DOCUMENTS
abstract: LEAD: The long-running Guinness scandal is again a focus of national attention, as new details, charges and countercharges in the case were revealed last week in a London high court.

headline: Eurosclerosis
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: VOLUME OFF
abstract: LEAD: Despite rising bond prices and a firmer dollar, the stock market slid yesterday for the second straight day, although trading was enlivened by special situations, including takeover rumors.

headline: North Korea Reported To Watch Carefully
abstract: LEAD: The civil unrest here has not significantly affected North Korean military movements, Gen. William J. Livsey, the senior American military commander in South Korea, said today.

headline: Moody's Lowers Chemical Ratings
abstract: LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation's debt ratings were reduced yesterday by Moody's, shortly before the bank holding company announced that it was no longer accruing interest on more than $1 billion of loans to Brazil.

headline: WHAT'S NEW ON THE SUPERMARKET SHELF; As American As Apple Pie - And Pizza
abstract: LEAD: IN the 1980's, pizza soared in popularity as its quality improved and people developed more eclectic and sophisticated tastes. ''Now it's just like apple pie,'' said Steve Braudo, marketing director for Little Lady Foods Inc. in Chicago, which makes Bravissimo pizza with new spinach, cheese and sausage toppings.

headline: DRESSING UP ROUTINE PAPERWORK
abstract: LEAD: WITH its new PS/2 series of computers, I.B.M. is beaming its spotlight on large corporations. Indeed, the new line would seem to be the opening act in a drama whose logical finale is a business environment in which everything is hooked up to, or at least able to communicate with, I.B.M.'s big mainframe computers.

headline: A.M.C. INCENTIVES
abstract: LEAD: The American Motors Corporation said it was offering new cost-cutting incentives on selected Renault cars and Jeep models beginning today and with no expiration date. The company said its Renault models would carry $500 rebate or various discount financing rates ranging from zero percent for two-year loans on subcompacts to 9.9 percent for five-year loans.

headline: AMERICAN WHO LOBBY FOR JAPAN
abstract: LEAD: THIS city's biggest growth industry is not high technolgy or real estate but high-powered lobbying for the Japanese.

headline: IMPATIENT LEADER ALTERING WARNACO
abstract: LEAD: When Linda J. Wachner and the financiers Frederick R. Adler and Leonard Shaykin went shopping for companies to acquire in 1985, Mr. Shaykin bet $50 that she could not learn to use a computer to crunch the numbers.

headline: BIC SAYS ITS LIGHTERS ARE SAFE
abstract: LEAD: The Bic Corporation denied yesterday that it faced mounting lawsuits on behalf of people who have been injured or killed by malfunctioning Bic disposable butane lighters. Reports of the lawsuits were included in an article in The New York Times.

headline: THATCHER CALLS JUNE 11 ELECTIONS, BUOYED BY A BIG LEAD IN THE POLLS
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today called a general election for June 11, a year ahead of schedule, and thus tied her political fortunes to an improving economy and her rising position in public-opinion polls.

headline: Gasoline Prices Steady
abstract: LEAD: Gasoline pump prices have stabilized, with less than a quarter-cent change during the last two weeks, according to Trilby Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter. The national average price for all grades of gasoline at both full- and self-service pumps was 96.31 cents a gallon for the two-week period ended last Friday.

headline: SECURITIES ISSUES SET A RECORD
abstract: LEAD: An environment of generally steady, low interest rates proved fertile for securities underwriters in the first quarter, and the volume of bonds and stock issued by corporations soared to a record.

headline: Shearson Picks Head Counsel
abstract: LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had named Robert C. Dinerstein executive vice president and general counsel. Mr. Dinerstein, 44 years old, will head the legal department and supervise Shearson Lehman Brothers' outside law firms. He will also be responsible for the secretary's office and corporate insurance.

headline: WARPLANE MAKERS FEEL PRESSURE TO COOPERATE
abstract: LEAD: When French Mirage and American F-18 fighters zoom overhead as the annual Paris Air Show begins on Thursday, the mood among the hundreds of military contractors here is expected to be as gray as Paris's skies have been in recent weeks.

headline: Judge Quits Hunts Case
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge who had rebuffed four defense requests to step down from the complex Hunt brothers bankruptcy case agreed today to turn the matter over to another judge because a bank merger could create a conflict of interest.

headline: Vitamin Programs Said to Cut Child Deaths in Third World
abstract: LEAD: Vitamin A supplements, long known to prevent blindness in malnourished children, may also reduce susceptibility to diseases often fatal to children in developing nations, according to testimony today before a House committee.

headline: A CHILEAN TREKS HOME FROM EXILE
abstract: LEAD: After 12 years of enforced exile abroad, Clodomiro Almeyda, who was one of the best-known members of the leftist Government of Salvadore Allende, climbed the eastern slopes of the Andes on a mule and made his way through a snow-covered mountain pass to come home to Chile.

headline: Dissident Journal Tests Gorbachev on 'Glasnost'
abstract: LEAD: A group of dissidents and freed political prisoners has published the first issue of a new, unofficial journal of news and opinion and has asked the Soviet Government for permission to distribute copies in the Soviet Union and abroad.

headline: A LAND OF SERBS AND ALBANIANS AND TROUBLE
abstract: LEAD: The church bells tolled at 5 A.M. to signal the protest, and the people lighted candles by the graves of their dead to bid their ancestors a sort of farewell.

headline: ECHOES OF NEW MOSCOW REACH SIBERIA, FAINTLY
abstract: LEAD: Tatyana M. Malinovskaya is the party boss in a county where reindeer outnumber people, 200,000 to 26,000. Her office in this gold-mining town in northeastern Siberia, opposite Alaska, is closer to Washington than to Moscow.

headline: A BOOK BY WALESA IS PRINTED IN PARIS
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, founder of the now-banned Solidarity labor union, says he likes to compare his country to a poor man who ''occupied a corner in a beautiful house that he did not own.''

headline: GORBACHEV ON A PRAGUE STROLL: THE CHEERS AND THE CURIOSITY
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today and walked among thousands of cheering Czechoslovaks who thronged streets that 19 years ago were cleared by invading Soviet tanks.

headline: Pope's Day: Nazi Camp and a Lecture to Poland
abstract: LEAD: Traveling close to the Soviet border today, Pope John Paul II evoked his homeland's violent past, praying over the ashes of death-camp victims, and he called for a re-examination of Poland's Communist system in order to bring a better future.

headline: ARGENTINE ARMY'S RUMBLINGS PERSIST
abstract: LEAD: New signs of discontent emerged in the Argentine Army today, this time in opposition to President Raul Alfonsin's choice of a new army Chief of Staff.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Aide Called a Principal in Iran Affair
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra inquiry said today that Thomas Clines, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, was a ''principal'' in his criminal investigation.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''Paul Volcker was the world's greatest financial crisis manager. Greenspan is going to be a rookie at that, so there has to be some uncertainty about how adroit he will be when the next crisis comes.''

headline: Group Buys 6.9% Of Cottrell Stock
abstract: LEAD: A group led by a New York investor, Alan B. Slifka, has purchased a 6.9 percent stake in Research-Cottrell Inc. The Somerville, N.J., construction and engineering company has received a bid of $43 a share, or $293 million, from a group that includes its chairman, Peter J. Gianacakes; Allen & Company and Odyssey Partners.

headline: Fleet Financial
abstract: LEAD: The Fleet Financial Corporation said its Fleet National Bank subsidiary would form a new investment banking unit. The new unit, Fleet Asssociates, will handle corporate finance, mortgage banking and real estate lending transactions. Richard A. Higginbotham, executive vice president of the bank, will head the division.

headline: Philips Discusses Medical Venture
abstract: LEAD: Philips Gloeilampen Fabrieken N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, said it was talking with the General Electric Company about a cooperative agreement between its medical unit and G.E.C.'s medical subsidiary, Picker International Inc.

headline: 'PEOPLE POWER,' KOREAN STYLE, FORCES PARTY CHIEF INTO BOLD POLITICAL GAMBLE
abstract: LEAD: With his startling decision today to capitulate to opposition demands for direct presidential elections, Roh Tae Woo acknowledged that the South Korean people could not be ignored.

headline: THATCHER CLAIMS HER THIRD VICTORY, BUT MARGIN DROPS
abstract: LEAD: After a bruising campaign, Margaret Thatcher claimed victory this morning in the British general election and a place in history as the first Prime Minister in this century to win three consecutive terms.

headline: Taxing the Rich
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: BUSH PRAISED NORTH, SECORD ASSERTS
abstract: LEAD: Hours after President Reagan dismissed Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North from the National Security Council, Vice President Bush telephoned Colonel North at a local hotel and offered warm praise for his work, according to Congressional testimony today.

headline: LOWER PRICES HURT PROFITS OF 3 BIG OIL CONCERNS
abstract: LEAD: Three large oil companies yesterday reported first-quarter earnings that were hurt by lower oil prices.

headline: Guatemalan Volcano Erupts
abstract: LEAD: The Pacaya volcano, 18 miles from here, began spewing lava and ash and caused a nearby town to be evacuated, a spokesman for the national observatory said today. The volcano, which has been sporadically active since January, erupted early Sunday. No injuries were reported but National Emergency Committee officials ordered the evacuation of the town of Caracol, which has a population of about 600.

headline: Agreement Is Reached On Spectradyne Buyout
abstract: LEAD: Spectradyne Inc., the nation's largest operator of pay-per-view hotel movie systems, said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $452 million, or $46 a share, in cash and securities.

headline: BRANCH SHOWROOMS FOR SATURN CARS
abstract: LEAD: Dealers selling Saturn cars, the well-publicized line of small automobiles due early in the next decade, will be expected to use branch showrooms in shopping malls and office buildings in a new approach to automobile retailing, executives of the General Motors Corporation subsidiary said today.

headline: NORTH TO BEGIN PUBLIC TESTIMONY JULY 7
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North will begin publicly testifying July 7 before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, according to an arrangement between the committees and Colonel North's lawyer that was announced today.

headline: A BUILDING BLOCK OFF THE OLD CHIP
abstract: LEAD: Silicon atoms, the foundation of today's computer industry, have been captured on film for the first time by photographers and researchers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The atoms, magnified a billion times, appear as ''hills'' on a silicon crystal. This photograph, made with a scanning tunneling microscope, is among 50 that make up a collection called ''Micro Scapes: The Hidden Art of High Technology,'' now on display in the Market at the Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street at Lexington Avenue.

headline: GOLDOME PLANS SWITCH BACK TO STATE CHARTER
abstract: LEAD: Citing an accounting dispute with Federal banking regulators and a desire for increased lending and investment powers, the Goldome Savings Bank said yesterday that it would seek to switch back to a state charter and then move to go public.

abstract: LEAD:         *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **    *3*D&N SAVINGS BANK (OTC)       Qtr to March 31   1987   1986                     Net inc   2,460,000   2,386,000              Per share   .77   .76

headline: Joint Trading Plan Advances
abstract: LEAD: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that they had approved the framework of a joint venture agreement to allow members to trade a wide variety of new contracts on either exchange.

headline: Security Pacific
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 3/8 percent notes, due in 1991, at a price of 99.875 to yield 8.412 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. Noncallable for life, the notes yield about 66-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Burlington Charges Paine Webber Leak
abstract: LEAD: Burlington Industries yesterday accused Paine Webber Inc. of leaking inside information about the textile producer to several parties, including Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, and Dominion Textile Inc. of Canada, to induce them to take over the company.

headline: Factory Orders Up 0.2%; Military Purchases Rise
abstract: LEAD: An increase in military purchases enabled factory orders for manufactured goods to edge up two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the smallest gain in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Florida Power and Light Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $350 million of first-mortgage bonds.

headline: VOTING IN VIETNAM IS REPORTED HEAVY
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam reported a heavy turnout today in general elections intended to ease out the Communist Party's old guard and bring in a new and more efficient government.

headline: SENATE PANEL VOTES AGAINST TESTING SPACE DEFENSE
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Armed Services Committee, spurning Administration efforts to loosen the interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, voted today to prohibit any tests that would violate the traditional view of the treaty.

headline: CHASE JOINS BANKS TAKING LOAN LOSS
abstract: LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday became the latest big lender to concede that a lot of its third world loans are uncollectible.

headline: BUYOUT PIONEER QUITTING FRAY
abstract: LEAD: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., whose name has become synonymous with one of the most important financial developments of the last decade, the leveraged buyout, has withdrawn from active participation in the firm he helped found and build into the industry's leader, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

headline: ZAMBIA-I.M.F. FALLOUT MIRRORS THIRD-WORLD WOES
abstract: LEAD: When President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia recently abandoned stringent austerity measures drawn up by the International Monetary Fund, he fueled the wide-ranging debate over whether the fund's policies represent the best prescription for heavily indebted third world economies.

headline: Aid Satisfies Indonesia
abstract: LEAD: Indonesia, its economy battered by a plunge in oil and commodity prices last year, said today that it would not reschedule its foreign debts and would neither devalue its currency nor impose foreign currency controls.

headline: REAGAN RESHPAING CONTRA AID DEBATE
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will seek to redefine the legislative debate over United States aid to the contras by muting a desire for military aid to overthrow the Sandinistas, White House officials said today.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                       Net Income    Percent           Jan.-March   Change           1987   From '86        Burlington Industries   $19,300,000    -       3.0        Dow Chemical Co.   246,000,000    +       40.6        Gillette Co.   55,000,000    +       22.2        Johnson Controls Inc.   12,200,000    +       10.9        Kimberly-Clark Corp.

headline: WEST GERMAN PARLIAMENT BACKS PLAN ON MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILES
abstract: LEAD: The West German Parliament today formally endorsed the Government's decision to support Soviet and American efforts to eliminate medium-range land-based missiles from Europe, though Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under fire from both left and right.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Richard E. Wasserman has joined Slater Hanft & Martin as a senior vice president.

headline: Dome's Creditors Oppose Amoco Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Amoco Corporation's proposed takeover of Canada's Dome Petroleum Ltd., which was outlined in detail Thursday, is unacceptable to creditors who must approve the deal, but bank sources said that they are hoping for a compromise. ''It was a nice try, a first shot,'' said a banker involved in assessing the deal, worth $5.2 billion Canadian, or $3.9 billion United States.

headline: Japanese Recovery Sign
abstract: LEAD: Japan's leading economic indicator continues pointing to a possible recovery in the near future, but Government economists caution that the yen's renewed upswing may do more economic damage. The Economic Planning Agency said today that the leading indicator for February, the latest reporting month, stood at 66.7, falling from 75 the previous month.

headline: Gulf States Utility
abstract: LEAD: The Gulf States Utilities Company said that its condition has ''significantly deteriorated'' and that its operating cash reserves would be inadequate by May unless it received additional financing or rate relief from state authorities in Texas and Louisiana. In its newly released annual report and 10-K filing, Gulf States said that bank lenders had notified it last month that no additional credit would be granted.

headline: Market Place; Hospital Stock Gains Forecast
abstract: LEAD: HOSPITAL management companies have suffered in recent years from a decline in patients - along with a decline in their stock prices - as a result of cutbacks by Medicare and efforts by private insurers to rein in their medical costs. But some Wall Street analysts now are taking a more positive view of selected companies in this once-thriving growth industry.

headline: CBS GAVE WYMAN $4.3 MILLION
abstract: LEAD: Thomas H. Wyman, the former chairman of CBS Inc. who was ousted in a board room revolt last September, received a settlement of more than $4.3 million and an annual payment of $400,000 for life, according to a CBS proxy statement released yesterday.

headline: U.S. SAYS CHINA IS ARMING IRAN, DESPITE DENIAL
abstract: LEAD: A top Reagan Administration official said today that Chinese officials had denied selling missiles to Iran, but that the United States did not believe the Chinese statements.

headline: PATENTS; A Dental Rinse For Plaque Removal
abstract: LEAD: Oral Research Laboratories, in New York, received a patent this week for a pre-brushing dental rinse trademarked Plax and the method of using it. It is said to remove more plaque than brushing alone can do.

headline: 15 Killed in Punjab Violence
abstract: LEAD: Fifteen people have been killed in Punjab in the last 24 hours, the worst violence this year in the northern Indian state, the Press Trust of India reported today. Seven of those deaths occurred when a gang of about 20 men on motor scooters swept through two villages near Amritsar, firing at everyone they saw, the news agency said.

headline: Olivetti Head in Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti is negotiating with a Spanish bank with a view to creating a joint investment concern to buy stakes in fast-growing Spanish companies, banking sources said today. Mr. de Benedetti is chairman of Italy's Olivetti group and head of his own independent finance group, Cofide.

headline: Rise Sought In Debt Limit
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury Department asked Congress today to swiftly raise the limit on Federal borrowing by $500 billion, to $2.8 trillion, to prevent the Government from running out of cash next month.

headline: JWT STOCK UP ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
abstract: LEAD: The stock of the JWT Group jumped yesterday as takeover rumors surrounded the advertising company.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Ameribanc Investors Group, Washington, and Cardinal Federal Savings and Loan Association, Cleveland, said the proposed acquisition of Cardinal by Ameribanc had been terminated by mutual agreement.

headline: FUTURES EXCHANGES WEIGH TIE
abstract: LEAD: Momentum to merge New York's two largest futures exchanges, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange, appears to be building.

headline: CPC's New Chairman
abstract: LEAD: James R. Eiszner. president and chief executive of CPC International Inc., was named to the additional post of chairman. Mr. Eiszner, 59 years old, succeeds James W. McKee Jr., 64, who plans to retire Sept. 1. CPC, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., produces Hellman's mayonnaise, Mazola margarine and Skippy peanut butter.

headline: THE DEFENDER OF ALLEGIS: RICHARD JESSE FERRIS
abstract: LEAD: Richard Jesse Ferris, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Allegis Corporation, has spent a decade trying to build a company that could take care of all the major needs of travelers. He has assembled a triad of companies - United Airlines for air service, the Westin and Hilton International chains for hotel rooms, and

headline: Upgrading Studied For Indiana Utility
abstract: LEAD: The Public Service Company of Indiana's bond rating is under review and could be raised from its current speculative grade status, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

headline: Sematech Gets $250 Million Budget
abstract: LEAD: The organizers of Sematech, the consortium of semiconductor companies acting to improve chip manufacturing technologies, said yesterday that a $250 million-a-year budget for the effort had been approved.

headline: Crazy Eddie Tender Stalled
abstract: LEAD: Entertainment Marketing Inc., the Houston electronics wholesaler that has made a bid for Crazy Eddie Inc., said yesterday that it would not make a tender offer for the 39-store chain without specific financial information it had requested from Crazy Eddie this month. The bid by Entertainment

headline: DOLE DISSENTS ON MOZAMBIQUE POLICY
abstract: LEAD: Senate Republicans are mounting an offensive to force the Reagan Administration to abandon its support for the Government of Mozambique and instead back an anti-Communist insurgent group with ties to South Africa.

headline: Wheeling Steel Post Created
abstract: LEAD: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said its directors had approved a plan to create an unusually powerful chief executive position to speed the company's reorganization in bankruptcy court.

headline: Busch Faces 2 Investigations
abstract: LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, parent of the world's largest brewer, said it was under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Federal grand jury over reports that some executives had received improper payments.

headline: KOHL URGES BROADENING OF ANY SHORT-RANGE MISSILE ACCORD
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl asserted today that any Soviet-American agreement to eliminate short-range nuclear missiles - those with ranges of 300 to 600 miles - must be accompanied by a ban on battlefield nuclear arms of even shorter range.

headline: Conferees Act to Speed Banks' Check-Clearing
abstract: LEAD: House and Senate conferees approved a compromise proposal today that would substantally reduce the time allowed to clear depositors' checks.

headline: Options Rule Set for Review
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to review its restriction against the trading of options of exchange-listed securities by more than one exchange.

headline: State Dept. Aide Backs Broad View of ABM Pact
abstract: LEAD: The State Department's legal adviser issued a report today arguing that the Antiballistic Missile Treaty does not ban President Reagan from authorizing tests of laser weapons and other devices for a space-based defense system.

headline: CHIP BATTLE GROWS IN EUROPE
abstract: LEAD: The decision by the Thomson Group of France and STET, the Italian state telecommunications enterprise, to form Western Europe's second-largest manufacturer of semiconductors demonstrates how the Europeans are trying to increase their share of a highly competitive market.

headline: APATHY IS ENEMY TO BOTH SIDES IN CAMBODIA
abstract: LEAD: On the eve of the traditional Buddhist New Year in Southeast Asia, both sides in Cambodia's unseen, unending war have been making urgent appeals for the trust and allegiance of the battle-weary Khmer people.

headline: Coming Attraction in Soviet: Festival of India
abstract: LEAD: With Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in attendance, a gentle Hindu invocation by an Indian singer at Cathedral Square at the Kremlin next Friday will start a huge celebration in the Soviet Union of India's art, culture, history and economic and scientific progress.

headline: CANADA CONSIDERS 10 NUCLEAR SUBS TO PATROL ARCTIC
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Government has concluded that it needs as many as 10 nuclear-powered submarines to enforce its claim to sovereignty in Arctic waters.

headline: DIVISIVE ISSUE IN ISRAEL: RENEWING TIES WITH MOSCOW
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union may soon discover that it is much easier to break diplomatic relations with Israel than it is to improve them.

headline: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS BACK IN THE BLACK
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments, enjoying a slight recovery in its semiconductor unit and benefiting from the previously announced settlement of certain patent infringement lawsuits, said today that it earned $83.8 million, or $3.12 a share, in the first quarter. It lost $23.8 million during last year's first quarter.

headline: JUDGE BROADENS LIABILITY OF ASBESTOS INSURERS
abstract: LEAD: A California judge ruled today that the largest possible number of insurance companies should be responsible for paying the claims of victims of asbestos-related diseases.

headline: TOKYO ASKING YEN RESTRAINT
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to halt the yen's rise in value, Japanese Government officials today summoned major Japanese participants in the foreign-exchange market and asked them to refrain from speculative currency trading.

headline: American General Buys Properties
abstract: LEAD: The American General Corporation, with the Newland Group Inc., said that it had agreed to buy the domestic residential projects of Genstar Land U.S.A. for about $200 million. Genstar, based in San Diego, is a subsidiary of Imasco Ltd. of Canada, a consumer products and services company that also owns Hardee's Food Systems Inc., Peoples Drug Stores Inc.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 11, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Texas Banks Get Approval to Merge
abstract: LEAD: The Republicbank Corporation and the Interfirst Corporation said they had received approval from their shareholders to complete their planned merger. The combination will create a bank holding company that is the largest in Texas and 12th largest in the United States. The two concerns said that the merger would be completed on June 6, and that the combined First Republicbank Corporation would open the following

headline: TWO ACCIDENTS RAISING QUESTIONS ABOUT FRANCE'S NUCLEAR PROGRAM
abstract: LEAD: Two accidents within days at French nuclear installations have prompted new concern about this country's ambitious nuclear power program.

headline: U.S. PUSH FOR ARMS EMBARGO ON IRAN HITS U.N. DEAD END
abstract: LEAD: The five permanent members of the Security Council have failed to agree on an American proposal to impose a global arms embargo against Iran, diplomats in Washington and at the United Nations said today.

headline: FLORIDA'S WIDE, INTRICATE REACH
abstract: LEAD: A NEW chapter in American tax policy will open tomorrow when Florida activates a controversial sales tax on services. The tax's reach will extend far beyond Florida's state lines.

headline: CONGRESS IS EXPECTED TO KEEP PRESSING FOR TRADE LEGISLATION
abstract: LEAD: White House sanctions against Japan may shore up the Administration's credibility in Congress to conduct trade policy, but they will not stop moves to enact tougher trade legislation, according to many legislators and trade analysts.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: LEAD: In percent          Tax-Exempt Bonds   7.82        Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index               Money Market Funds   5.91        Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield               Bank Money Market Accounts   5.50        Bank Rate Monitor               Home Mortgage   10.47        Federal Home Loan Bank, national average               Unsecured Personal Loans        Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity        Chase Manhattan, New York   14.50        Continental Illinois, Chicago   14.00        Bank of America, San Francisco   18.25

headline: CATCHING SPIES: INTELLIGENCE OFFICIALS SAY U.S. LACKS THE RESOLVE TO IMPROVE
abstract: LEAD: As President Reagan awaits new Government recommendations on altering counterespionage policy, present and former intelligence officials said that the problems were already well known but that the Government apparently lacked the resolve to solve them.

headline: DOW PASSES 2,400 ON A 15.20 ADVANCE
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 2,400 for the first time in early trading yesterday and finished the day up 15.20 points, at 2,405.54.

headline: COSTA RICA CRITICIZES CONTRA AID
abstract: LEAD: The President of Costa Rica renewed his criticism today of American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, saying it had given the Sandinista Government an excuse to be repressive and to dismiss its economic failures.

headline: Tokyo Stock Record
abstract: LEAD: Encouraged by yesterday's rally on Wall Street and the yen's depreciation against the dollar, stock prices set a record today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The Nikkei Stock Average, comprising 225 issues, rose by 202.75 yen to close the morning trading session at 24,088.85 yen, passing the psychological barrier of 24,000 yen.

headline: Plans for Two-Year Notes Expected
abstract: LEAD: Today's regular auctions of new Treasury bills due in three and six months are the only sales of Government securities scheduled this week. On Wednesday, securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce plans for a two-year note auction on April 22.

headline: FOR FILIPINO GUNMAKER, ELECTION BOLSTERS BUSINESS
abstract: LEAD: In these hard times in the Philippines, Benjamin Barriga is a craftsman with a steady trade.

headline: SOUTH KOREANS RIOT IN NIGHT, THEN GO DUTIFULLY TO WORK
abstract: LEAD: Citizens take to the streets at night here and in other cities to demonstrate against the Government, but during the day they are hard at work, driving an economy that booms even amid political turmoil.

headline: Some New Caledonians Fear Clash Over Vote
abstract: LEAD: On the country roads outside the capital of this South Pacific island group, ubiquitous graffiti announce that a visitor is entering Kanaky.

headline: RASHID KARAMI, COOL PERSUADER IN A LAND OF STRIFE
abstract: LEAD: Rashid Karami, who was assassinated in an explosion aboard his helicopter yesterday, was an adroit, flexible pro-Syrian politician who had been the Prime Minister of Lebanon 10 times since 1955.

headline: AUSTRALIANS BUY BONWIT TELLER
abstract: LEAD: Bonwit Teller, the century-old fashion chain whose flagship store is a mainstay in Trump Tower on 57th Street, has been sold by the Allied Stores Corporation to Hooker Corporation Ltd. for $101 million in cash, top executives of both companies said yesterday.

headline: Mt. Etna Eruption Kills Two
abstract: LEAD: Ashes, gases and tons of rocks showered tourists on Mount Etna today, killing an 8-year-old French boy and his mother and injuring seven people, officials said. The police in this city on Sicily's eastern coast said all nine were among a group of tourists who were caught in a brief eruption while walking near the volcano's summit.

headline: NUMBER TO CALL FOR PASSENGER DATA
abstract: LEAD: People who believe their relatives might have been aboard the Polish airliner that crashed today can call (212) 944-8116 for information, a State Department spokeswoman announced.

headline: FOES OF APARTHEID SEE MAJOR GAIN
abstract: LEAD: Citibank, long a vocal opponent of corporate withdrawal from South Africa, gave in to the trend yesterday and said it would sell its subsidiary there.

headline: DOW, IN REBOUND, ADVANCES BY 11.22
abstract: LEAD: A stronger dollar and a mild improvement in Treasury bond prices combined to lift the Dow Jones industrial average 11.22 points, to 2,372.16 yesterday, one day after its fifth-worst decline ever.

headline: Testimony by Volcker Helps to Bolster Dollar
abstract: LEAD: The dollar firmed on world currency markets yesterday, bolstered by strong statements from the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, and the news that Japanese interest rates would be lowered again soon.

headline: Advertising; Expansion Continues At WCRS
abstract: LEAD: THE WCRS Group of London, which last year acquired HBM/ Creamer and Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, announced yesterday that it was well on the way toward purchasing Robert A. Becker Inc., a New York-based health-care ad agency, and two companies in Australia.

headline: Silverstein Group Signs Accountants
abstract: LEAD: The accounting firm of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company will lease 240,000 square feet at 7 World Trade Center, a $300 million project being developed by Silverstein Properties Inc. The long-term lease represents a commitment of more than $200 million, according to analysts.

headline: La Roche-Lilly
abstract: LEAD: Officials of Eli Lilly & Company and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. have reached a license agreement covering a human growth hormone. Lilly began marketing the hormone in late March. A statement issued by Hoffmann-La Roche said the agreement had been reached ''as an alternative to litigation.''

headline: PROTESTERS FIGHT SEOUL RIOT POLICE AS TENSIONS RISE
abstract: LEAD: Defying a Government warning to stop their protests or face extraordinary measures, thousands of students took to the streets today, skirmishing with riot policemen in the capital and other major cities.

headline: ALLEGIS FACES CUT IN RATINGS
abstract: LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that they were considering cutting their bond ratings for the Allegis Corporation and its United Airlines and Hertz rental car subsidiaries because of the company's proposed recapitalization plan.

headline: Japan Investing Abroad
abstract: LEAD: Japanese investment overseas nearly doubled in the last financial year, to a record $22.32 billion, the Government said today, with 46 percent of the money spent in the United States. Nearly half the total invested abroad was used to buy into foreign companies. A large share was lent to foreign concerns in which Japanese investors already had a stake.

headline: Yields Flat Or Up a Bit
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money-market accounts and money-market mutual funds were unchanged to slightly higher for the week ended yesterday.

headline: EGYPTIAN VOTE IS MOSTLY PEACEFUL
abstract: LEAD: Scattered outbreaks of violence were reported today as Egyptians voted to elect a national legislature.

headline: Newspaper Bureau
abstract: LEAD: At a meeting of its board of directors the Newspaper Advertising Bureau re-elected its slate of officers headed by Frank A. Daniels Jr., president and publisher of The Raleigh News & Observer and Times.

headline: TEXT OF SOVIET STATEMENT
abstract: LEAD: Following is the official text of the Politburo statement on the dismissal of Aleksandr I. Koldunov as commander of the Soviet antiaircraft forces, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency. A separate Government statement on the dismissal of the Defense Minister, Marshal Sergei L.

headline: Sentences of Five Jazz Buffs Are Upheld in Czechoslovakia
abstract: LEAD: A judge rejected appeals today and confirmed the sentences of five jazz fans who led a cultural group. More than 100 supporters clapped and chanted outside the courtroom.

headline: Marine Prosecutors Outline Spying Case Against Guard
abstract: LEAD: Military prosecutors began outlining their case today as pretrial hearings opened for a Marine guard charged with espionage while assigned to the United States Embassy in Moscow.

headline: First Boston Official Is Back
abstract: LEAD: The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday that T. Anthony Brooks was returning to the investment banking house as managing director of its equity capital market department after a hiatus of 15 years. In his new role, Mr. Brooks will be managing First Boston's sizable business in new stock issues.

headline: IN VENICE, WASHINGTON'S PARTNERS RESIST ECHOING TOUGH TALK ON THE GULF
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the major industrial democracies reacted cautiously today to the Reagan Administration's tough comments on the situation in the Persian Gulf, an issue that has threatened the seven-nation summit conference here.

headline: MITTERRAND CLOSING A WOUND IN CANADA
abstract: LEAD: In a visit filled with symbolism for Quebec and its new accommodation with the rest of Canada, Francois Mitterrand today became the first French President to visit this city since Charles de Gaulle called for a ''free Quebec'' 20 years ago.

headline: Norway's Foreign Aid
abstract: LEAD: Norway provided more foreign aid to developing countries as a percentage of its gross national product than any other Western industrialized nation, a Foreign Aid Ministry spokeman said Friday. He added that Norway gave almost six billion crowns, or $900 million - 1.16 percent of its total of goods and services - in aid last year to United Nations bodies, the World Bank and other organizations.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Bell Resources Financial Services is offering $200 million of convertible bonds, due in 2002, with an interest rate of 5 to 5 1/4 percent, through Nomura International Ltd.

headline: Nations Trim I.M.F. Debt
abstract: LEAD: Poor countries are paying back more to the International Monetary Fund than they are getting in new loans, and the difference rose sharply to about $1.69 billion in the first quarter. In the first quarter of last year the net payback was about $226 million.

headline: Becor Western
abstract: LEAD: Becor Western Inc. said it had adjourned its annual shareholders meeting to evaluate a possible takeover offer from a new unidentified bidder. The company said it was also examining a bid from Davis Mining and Manufacturing Inc. and a merger proposal from BCW Acquisition, a buyout group formed by members of Becor Management and Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Customs Held Drexel Official
abstract: LEAD: Robert Kramer, a vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert, was detained last Friday by United States Customs agents as he was leaving the Bahamas for failing to declare $88,000 in cash and securities in his possession, Drexel officials confirmed yesterday.

headline: Rimma Bravve IS Dead at 32; Soviet Emigre Fought Cancer
abstract: LEAD: Rimma Bravve, a cancer patient who sought to emigrate from the Soviet Union for eight years before she was granted an exit visa last December, died yesterday at her mother's home in Rochester. She was 32 years old.

headline: DRUGS AND GRAFT MAIN ISSUE IN BAHAMAS VOTE
abstract: LEAD: With the most important national elections in the recent history of the Bahamas scheduled for next Friday, only one issue dominates the campaign: drug trafficking and the official Government corruption it has spawned.

headline: 24 Political Prisoners To Be Freed by Seoul
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Ministry said today that it would release 24 political prisoners on Monday in an amnesty marking the birthday of Buddha, an official holiday. In addition, it said, 1,082 others in jail for other crimes will be released.

headline: EXPERTS EXPRESS PESSIMISM ON SAVINGS INDUSTRY'S FUTURE
abstract: LEAD: With hundreds of the nation's savings and loan associations insolvent, many experts maintain that Congressional rescue plans are inadequate and that the system cannot survive without tens of billions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

headline: China Opens Fifth Market
abstract: LEAD: China opened a fifth securities market this week, but expansion of stock trading is now being given a low priority because it is too ideologically sensitive, according to various officials and Chinese newspapers.

headline: NEW PEACE EFFORT IN NORTH AFRICA
abstract: LEAD: Morocco and Algeria have agreed to start talks to resolve the 11-year-old war in Western Sahara at the personal urging of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.

headline: BONN CHECKS REPORT OF SMUGGLING OF ATOMIC TECHNOLOGY TO PAKISTAN
abstract: LEAD: The Cologne prosecutor's office has begun an investigation of a West German company that is suspected of illegally exporting plans that may have helped Pakistan build a uranium enrichment plant. Such a plant could be used in making nuclear weapons.

headline: Egypt Breaks All Diplomatic Ties With Iran
abstract: LEAD: Egypt announced today that it was breaking all diplomatic ties with Iran, shutting down Iran's two-member interests section here and recalling Cairo's single diplomat in Teheran.

abstract: LEAD: The Army on Friday shifted its ordering for front-line M-1A1 tanks to a multiyear contract, setting a four-year, $3.45 billion deal with the General Dynamics Corporation. Under the contract, General

headline: First Boston's Merger With Allegheny Halted
abstract: LEAD: The First Boston Corporation and Allegheny International said yesterday that they had called off their $500 million merger because they were unable to obtain two-thirds of Allegheny's preferred stock.

headline: APOLLO'S PRODUCTS
abstract: LEAD: Apollo Computer Inc. introduced new computer work stations and said it had improved the performance and reduced the prices of some of its existing work stations. The company also introduced new products to allow personal computers to communicate with the work stations. The new products, the Domain Series 4000 Personal Super Work

headline: 3 PANAMA PAPERS WON'T PUBLISH WITH CENSORSHIP
abstract: LEAD: Three of Panama's six morning newspapers failed to appear today after editors refused to submit articles for censorship.

headline: Combination Unit Steams, Roasts, Bakes
abstract: LEAD: ANDRE SOLTNER, proprietor and chef of Lutece, recalled how his assistants balked at the idea of installing a new type of oven in the kitchen of the world-famous restaurant. ''They told me I was crazy and that they did not want to use the oven,'' Mr. Soltner said. ''I now have to fight to get to it.

headline: B.P. ACQUISITION
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. has completed its merger with the Standard Oil Company, raising its holding in the Cleveland-based oil company to 100 percent, from 55 percent. The acquisition was made through B.P.'s wholly owned subsidiary, B.P. America Inc. Sir Peter Walters, B.P.'s chairman, will serve as chairman of B.P.

headline: MANY KILLED IN AFGHAN BATTLE
abstract: LEAD: A monthlong battle around Afghanistan's second largest city, Kandahar, has left hundreds of combatants and civilians dead and wounded, guerrilla sources here said today.

headline: Sakharov Assails Body For Not Defending Him
abstract: LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov castigated the Soviet Academy of Sciences today for failing to protest what he called his ''illegal deportation'' to the city of Gorky, where he was confined for nearly seven years for his support of Soviet dissidents.

headline: Ice Cream Plays: Three Choices
abstract: LEAD: With the peak ice cream season near, investors are looking for profits in America's appetite for the frozen dessert. And, in fact, the stocks of two small companies have been rising with the temperature.

abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed three men believed to be strong allies to the Communist Party Politburo yesterday, raising the membership of the key policy-making body to 14 and consolidating his power. Here is the current Politburo lineup, including voting full members and nonvoting candidate members, and the members who have left since Mr.

headline: FILIPINOS, REBUILDING DEMOCRATIC RULE, CAST VOTES FOR A LEGISLATURE
abstract: LEAD: Filipinos were voting today for a new legislature that will restore the country's democratic institutions and limit the powers of President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: TRADE PACT FOES RALLY IN CANADA
abstract: LEAD: As President Reagan arrived here today for a 24-hour official visit, a coalition of Canadian groups including the Canadian Labor Congress, the country's biggest trade union organization, completed formation of a new lobbying body to campaign against any broadly based trade agreement with the United

headline: Banks Bilked Of $1.1 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The United States banking industry lost an estimated $1.1 billion to fraud and embezzlement last year, and theft by insiders was a factor in about one-third of all bank failures, bank regulators said today.
