abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday  None  Tuesday  Consumer Prices May Durable Goods Orders May  Wednesday  None  Thursday  None  Friday

headline: EX-CHAIRMAN SUES GUINNESS IN OUSTER
abstract: LEAD: Sir Norman Macfarlane, the new chairman of Guinness P.L.C., said today that the scandal-plagued company's former chairman, Ernest Saunders, was suing Guinness for unfair dismissal.

headline: Rolls Jet Unit's Sales Rules Set
abstract: LEAD: The British Government, giving the details of its previously announced plan to sell the state-owned Rolls-Royce Ltd. to the public next month, said today that each investor would have to buy a minimum of 400 shares. The price will depend on market conditions.

headline: BLOW TO CONTRAS SEEN IF CHIEF QUITS
abstract: LEAD: The expected departure of Alfonso Robelo, a centrist, from the Nicaraguan rebel leadership would be another blow to the Administration's policy in Central America, Administration officials said today.

headline: Administration Split on Dollar
abstract: LEAD: AS Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone arrives in Washington for his crucial talks with President Reagan, there are uncertainties and divisions within the American camp on the matter of greatest immediate concern to the Japanese: the yen-dollar exchange rate.

headline: NORTH TO BE GRANTED LIMITED IMMUNITY
abstract: LEAD: Over the objection of the special prosecutor, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair voted today to compel testimony from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North by granting him limited immunity from prosecution.

headline: Antitrust Lawsuit Against Coastal
abstract: LEAD: The Trans-American Natural Gas Corporation filed a $100 million lawsuit in Federal court, charging the Coastal Corporation and its chairman, Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., with antitrust violations.

headline: Cyclops Unit Plan
abstract: LEAD: Dixons Group P.L.C., which won control of the Cyclops Corporation after a protracted takeover battle, said it might sell Cyclops's Busy Beaver Building Centers Inc. unit, which operates 11 hardware stores. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Dixons did not say whether the company had been contacted by interested buyers.

headline: DOW UP 10.05 AMID MODEST TRADING
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average had a good session yesterday, even though the overall stock market was mixed in modest trading.

headline: Robelo Plans to Quit Contra Umbrella Group
abstract: LEAD: Alfonso Robelo, the last of the original three directors of the largest bloc of Nicaraguan rebels, said today that he would soon quit the organization's top leadership and would not be a candidate for one of seven slots of an expanded directorate that will be chosen in the next few weeks.

headline: PROPOSAL SEEKS TO AID RETIREE HEALTH FUNDS
abstract: LEAD: Some companies have billions of dollars in overfunded retiree pension plans. And some of those same companies need billions of dollars for underfunded retiree health plans.

headline: Europe Rejects Japan's Plea
abstract: LEAD: The European Court of Justice rejected today an appeal by five Japanese companies against anti-dumping duties imposed by the European Community. The decision came at a time of worsening trade relations between Japan and the 12-nation trade bloc.

headline: NET FALLS AT CHEMICAL, IRVING
abstract: LEAD: Three large banking companies yesterday reported lower first-quarter earnings that reflected the negative impact of Brazil's suspension of interest payments.

headline: Stocks End Mixed; Dow Gains 7.08
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday for the second day, as rises by blue-chip issues were offset by declines in the broader market. Investors appeared cautious, content to wait on the sidelines until the releases by the Government today of trade figures and tomorrow of producer price statistics.

headline: THATCHER'S GOAL: A CHANGED BRITAIN
abstract: LEAD: Margaret Thatcher is seeking much more than the record for longevity she will have within her grasp if she leads her party to its third straight election victory June 11. She is really running for a place on that short list of Prime Ministers who have profoundly altered this change-resistant nation.

headline: SLOW RISE IN BORROWING COSTS SEEN
abstract: LEAD: The rise in the prime rate this week has raised alarm that interest rates have finally bottomed out and now are edging higher.

headline: MOSCOW WEIGHING NAVAL ESCORTS
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today that it would rent three tankers to Kuwait to transport oil through the Persian Gulf, and raised the possibility that Soviet warships might escort them.

headline: Resignation at Wachovia
abstract: LEAD: Thomas Williams will leave his post as chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation, one of the South's leading regional banks, on April 30 to form a private investing company. Mr. Williams, who oversaw the merger of First Atlanta and First Wachovia in December 1985 to form a bank with assets of $18.7 billion, said today that he had accomplished his objectives.

headline: Crazy Eddie Inc.
abstract: LEAD: The Chemical Bank has cut off a $52 million letter of credit with Crazy Eddie Inc., the 39-store retail electronics chain. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Crazy Eddie said the bank had withdrawn the credit, but did not elaborate. The filing said that Crazy Eddie had $10 million outstanding under the credit line.

headline: LAND IN CRISIS LOOKS ANEW AT BATTLES OF YEARS AGO
abstract: LEAD: Their faces appear on the national currency, their names adorn countless streets and plazas. But 77 years after the eruption of the Mexican Revolution, the leaders of that cataclysmic period are little more than vague and fading images to millions of their countrymen.

headline: Dollar Outlook Helps Yields
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices declined sharply yesterday as the specter of a weaker dollar continued to weigh heavily on the minds of investors and speculators.

headline: FROM AN EDUCATION CHIEF, TOUGH TALK AND POLITICS
abstract: LEAD: The morning after he was denounced in the House of Commons as the ''most hated minister of education there has ever been,'' Kenneth Baker brushed aside suggestions that his headlong push for a new education policy could backfire politically against his boss, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1987
abstract: LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The House approved a restrictive trade bill amendment, reflecting disarray over the direction of a new trade policy. The measure, proposed by Representative Gephardt, requires retaliation according to a rigid formula against countries such as Japan, whose large trade surpluses with the United States have grown, in part by shutting out American products.

headline: Dollar Falls Versus Yen After Yeutter Remark
abstract: LEAD: An apparently innocuous statement by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, helped send the dollar lower against the yen in foreign-exchange trading today.

headline: QUIZZING OF SECORD IS SEEN AS SEEKING A CONSPIRACY CASE
abstract: LEAD: The select Congressional committees pressed Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord today about his conduct in the Iran-contra affair, apparently in an effort to show that he had been part of a conspiracy with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to violate Congressional restrictions on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: MAN AND GOD IN CUBA: A CASTRO-CHURCH DETENTE?
abstract: LEAD: The young Cuban sat in the cool, shaded courtyard of one of the graceful old churches of Havana talking about his mother and religion.

headline: Gencorp Settles TV Station Sale
abstract: LEAD: Gencorp Inc. said that it had reached an agreement for the previously announced sale of its television station KHJ-TV of Los Angeles to the Walt Disney Company. Gencorp also announced the settlement of a Federal Communications Commission proceeding involving the station. As previously reported, Disney agreed to pay a base price of $320 million to buy the independent television station.

headline: NAKASONE SUFFERS A SEVERE SETBACK AS JAPAN'S LEADER
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone suffered a severe political defeat tonight when an emboldened opposition forced him to set aside his plans for a new sales tax.

headline: Search Begins for a New Director for Unesco
abstract: LEAD: The search has begun for a successor to Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

headline: POSSIBLE CHUN SUCESSORS
abstract: LEAD: Although President Chun Doo Hwan says he will step down next February, it is generally assumed that he wants to designate his successor.

headline: Business and the Law; Patent Fight Over Genetics
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the gavel goes down in the High Court of Justice in London's Old Bailey today, it will mark a new chapter in the war between biotechnology companies over the valuable rights to drugs created by genetic engineering.

headline: F.B.I. CHIEF REPORTEDLY TOLD MEESE TO QUIT INQUIRY
abstract: LEAD: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, urged Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to disqualify himself from the investigation of the Iran-contra affair last November, according to Administration officials.

headline: Shifting Costs To Employees
abstract: LEAD: EVER since the Depression, employers have been bearing more and more of the costs of their workers' medical care.

headline: 2 Months Without Pay Sparks Yugoslav Strike
abstract: LEAD: About 1,000 construction workers have gone on strike in Skoplje, in the southern republic of Macedonia, to protest a lack of wages for two months, the Belgrade daily Politika said today.

headline: Corrections
abstract: LEAD: An article in some copies yesterday about opposition by New York City's district attorneys to Mayor Koch's proposed budget quoted a word incorrectly in a comment from District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan. He said, ''I think the nicest thing you can say about the Mayor and the Budget Director is that they've got their heads in the sand.

abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: SPAIN FEARS BOMBING MAY HERALD AN INCREASE IN TERRORIST ATTACKS
abstract: LEAD: A car-bombing in Barcelona that killed 17 people at a crowded supermarket has provoked expressions of anguish and outrage and concern over the future tactics of Basque separatist guerrillas.

headline: Morgan Grenfell Official Joins Unit of Citicorp
abstract: LEAD: John B. Fraser, the president of Morgan Grenfell Inc., the New York-based subsidiary of the British merchant bank, has left to become a managing director in the mergers and acquisitions department of the Citicorp Investment Bank.

headline: President and Chief Named by Ann Taylor
abstract: LEAD: Michele Fortune, senior vice president and a general merchandise manager of apparel at Lord & Taylor, will become president and chief executive officer of Ann Taylor, the fashion chain operated by the Allied Stores Corporation, on July 6.

headline: Carbide Seeks Adjournment
abstract: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation applied to the Bhopal district court today to adjourn legal proceedings until October, the United News of India reported.

headline: CUTS BY JAPAN NOW SPUR FEARS OF CHIP SHORTAGE
abstract: LEAD: Japan's moves to cut the production of computer chips could lead to a shortage of the vital semiconductors, some computer and semiconductor industry executives said today.

headline: INQUIRY BY WALSH SAID TO SCRUTINIZE HIGH U.S. OFFICIALS
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that his investigation covered ''high Government officials'' as well as others and gave his strongest indication to date that he would seek indictments.

headline: NO PRIZES IN POPULARITY FOR THE CHINESE IN TIBET
abstract: LEAD: Four green-uniformed Chinese policemen swaggered into a small restaurant on Xinfu Road, drank tea and left without paying. The restaurant owner, a Tibetan, shrugged. ''There is nothing we can do,'' he said. ''The police never pay. Who would we complain to?''

headline: MUBARAK PARTY WINS IN EGYPT'S VOTE
abstract: LEAD: The National Democratic Party of President Hosni Mubarak retained its overwhelming control of the Egyptian legislature in elections Monday, but an alliance including Moslem fundamentalists established itself as the most powerful opposition party, according to preliminary results disclosed today.

headline: A 'BIG BORE,' A LA BRASILIA, IN THE MIDDLE OF NIGERIA
abstract: LEAD: A European contractor slowed his Mercedes to allow a herd of long-horned cattle to cross a boulevard of this future metropolis and remarked, ''It's easier to make international telephone calls than at home.''

headline: Profits Surge At Manville
abstract: LEAD: The Manville Corporation, citing improved conditions in its principal markets, said its first-quarter profit more than doubled, to $42.9 million, or $1.52 a share, from $17.5 million, or 47 cents a share, in the 1986 period. Sales climbed 6.7 percent, to $475 million, from $445.3 million.

headline: U.S. AND FRANCE IN ARMS TALKS ACCORD
abstract: LEAD: The United States and France have reached a tentative agreement on ways for the West to negotiate with the Soviet Union on conventional arms, a senior State Department official said today.

headline: Rohatyn Asks Market Study
abstract: LEAD: Felix Rohatyn, the senior partner in the investment banking firm of Lazard Freres & Company, called today for the establishment of a commission to recommend changes in Federal securities laws.

headline: Variety of Offerings Set This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week consist of today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed by the regular monthly sale of two-year notes on Wednesday.

headline: Living Together, in Sickness and Health
abstract: LEAD: UNMARRIED couples who have lived together for years may feel as if they were married, but in legal terms nothing could be further from the truth. During life, the partners generally do not qualify for such tax-free benefits as employer-sponsored health insurance that spouses routinely receive. And at death, they do not automatically inherit a share of their deceased partner's property.

headline: Deposed Fiji Prime Minister Sues New Regime as Illegal
abstract: LEAD: The Prime Minister deposed in the May 14 coup in Fiji filed a lawsuit today seeking a return to power.

headline: Separatists Kill 5 in India
abstract: LEAD: Sikh separatists in the north Indian state of Punjab have killed five people and burned more liquor, tobacco and barber shops, the police said today. The militants have burned and looted more than 150 shops in the last month. Alcohol, smoking and the cutting of hair are forbidden by the Sikh religion, but the campaign is also seen as an attempt to destabilize the state's Sikh Government.

headline: France Pardons Chinese Spy Who Pretended to Be Woman
abstract: LEAD: A Chinese man jailed in France last year for espionage activities has been pardoned by President Francois Mitterrand, judicial officials said today.

headline: A Polish Airlines Jet Makes Emergency Warsaw Landing
abstract: LEAD: A Polish airliner bound for Baghdad with 110 people aboard safely made an emergency landing in Warsaw after the pilot found a malfunction in the plane's equipment, an air-traffic controller said today.

headline: Inside Children's Television
abstract: LEAD: CY SCHNEIDER has written a book titled ''Children's Television, the Art, the Business and How it Works.'' And having five children is only one of his credentials.

headline: Report on Orange Crop
abstract: LEAD: The nation's orange harvest for the 1986-87 crop season is estimated at 183 million boxes, down 4 percent from the May forecast but still 4 percent more than last season, the Agriculture Department said.

headline: MORE FROM HEARINGS: THE EX-C.I.A. COUNSEL
abstract: LEAD: As the Iran-contra hearings continued in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Stanley Sporkin. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: Arsenal Conducts Zero Coupon Sale
abstract: LEAD: Arsenal Acquiring Inc. is offering nearly $400 million of zero coupon senior subordinated debentures due in 2002 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Arsenal is a subsidiary of National Amusements Inc., a motion picture exhibitor, which is acquiring Viacom International in a leveraged buyout.

headline: Britain Issues Threat to Japan
abstract: LEAD: In an attempt to put pressure on Japan to resolve a trade dispute, Britain today identified at least 58 Japanese companies for possible expulsion within weeks and threatened to deny business licenses to Japanese applicants.

headline: Sosnoff Seeks Help In Caesars Bid
abstract: LEAD: The New York investor Martin J. Sosnoff has asked other Caesars World Inc. shareholders to help him in his battle for control of the Los Angeles-based gambling concern. Mr. Sosnoff wants Caesars shareholders to remove the four inside directors from the nine-member board, to repeal certain antitakeover measures and to block any recapitalization that would involve additional debt without prior shareholder approval.

headline: Iran's Fast Missile: What It Can Do
abstract: LEAD: The Chinese-built missiles recently obtained by Teheran have a range of 50 miles and a warhead weighing 1,100 pounds.

headline: WILL BOOZE AND PERRIER BE OBSOLETE?
abstract: LEAD: LAST September, just before the World Series was to begin, The New York Post asked Mets star Howard Johnson about his biggest worry going into the pennant race.

headline: Trade Surplus In Canada Cut
abstract: LEAD: Canada's merchandise trade surplus was sliced by a quarter in March, as imports grew for the second consecutive month and exports fell, Statistics Canada said today.

headline: American Express Net Off 21.4% in First Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that its net income fell 21.4 percent in the first quarter.

headline: Two Russian Guards Killed by Guerrillas Near Afghan Border
abstract: LEAD: Afghan guerrillas attacked an outpost of Soviet border guards last week and killed two of them, the official press agency Tass said today.

headline: Mechanical Engineers In Demand
abstract: LEAD: MECHANICAL engineers represent one of the oldest engineering specialties. Biotechnology companies are one of the newest growth industries. And the new has a desperate need for the old.

headline: A Trip to the Market to Get Some Money
abstract: LEAD: At one point in his testimony, Robert W. Owen provided details of a trip to New York to get money from a market on the Lower West Side.

headline: Market Place; Limited's Move In Men's Wear
abstract: LEAD: AFTER five years of dramatic success in building the nation's largest retail women's apparel chain, The Limited Inc. created some surprise at its annual meeting in Columbus, Ohio, Monday with an announcement that it would enter the men's apparel field. Yesterday, company watchers on Wall Street, with varying degrees of enthusiasm, endorsed the retailer's move to open 15 experimental Express

headline: Allegheny Sales
abstract: LEAD: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation said it had signed separate definitive purchase agreements, contingent upon financing, covering the sales of its laundry services and office furniture divisions. The laundry services division is being sold for $72.5 million in cash, and the office furniture unit is being sold for $12 million, with $6.5 million to be received in cash and the remainder to be financed by Allegheny.

headline: Panama General Accused of Ousting Leader
abstract: LEAD: A former Panamanian military commander today accused the armed forces chief, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, of involvement in electoral fraud and the ouster of President Nicolas Ardito Barletta in 1985.

headline: French Steel Merger Likely
abstract: LEAD: France's two giant state-owned steel companies, Usinor and Sacilor, are likely to merge completely this year in an overhaul of the industry following huge losses, the two groups' joint president said today.

headline: HIGH COURT BARS A WALL ST. APPEAL ON ROLE OF BANKS
abstract: LEAD: The nation's banks won another battle today in their bitter competition with Wall Street as the Supreme Court left standing a ruling that permits the banks to help companies raise money through the sale of short-term debt.

headline: MAIL-ORDER SALES TAX STUDIED BY HOUSE PANEL
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to help state governments extend their taxable reach to the growing direct-marketing industry, a Congressional panel today began considering legislation to require mail-order retailers like L.L. Bean Inc. to collect sales taxes on out-of-state purchases.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Apache Corp. is offering $90 million of Ba-3/BB- rated 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at 100 through Smith Barney, Harris Upham. Noncallable for two years, the debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $13.875 a share.

headline: Trade Deficit Down 2.3%
abstract: LEAD: The deficit in the broadest measure of United States foreign trade showed a slight improvement in the first three months of this year, but it was not enough to keep the country from plunging further as the world's largest debtor, the Government said today, The Commerce Department said the imbalance in the nation's current account narrowed to $37.12 billion in the January

headline: Ogilvy and Grey Post First-Quarter Results
abstract: LEAD: The Ogilvy Group and Grey Advertising both released their first-quarter financial statements on Friday.

headline: Spectradyne Bid Withdrawn
abstract: LEAD: Marvin Davis, the Denver oil executive, said yesterday that he was withdrawing his bid for Spectradyne Inc. because another offer has been made.

headline: Citicorp Recruits At Goldman, Sachs
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp Investment Bank, which in recent years has seen a number of its top traders desert for higher pay and greater freedom at Wall Street firms, scored a victory yesterday. It hired David A. Jones, the manager of fixed-income trading operations for Goldman, Sachs & Company in London, to head a new trading division in New

headline: Troop Buildup Raises China-India Border Tension
abstract: LEAD: American officials reported increasing concern today about rising tension between India and China as a result of a buildup of Indian and Chinese troops in a disputed, mountainous border region near Bhutan. The State Department has urged both sides to keep the situation calm, officials said.

headline: Today's Auction Cut to $12.8 Billion
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financing this week is limited to the bill market, where the regular Monday auction of three- and six-month issues will be followed Tuesday by a sale of one-year bills.

headline: Hispanic Unit at Doner
abstract: LEAD: W. B. Doner & Company, Detroit, has established a Hispanic unit for specialty advertising and has brought in Isaac Lasky and Roberto Manzano to run it. Mr. Lasky was last at Coca-Cola U.S.A., where he was manager of Hispanic consumer marketing. Mr. Manzano, who will be creative director, last held that role at Castor Spanish International in New York.

headline: U.S. Professor Convicted in West Bank Disorders
abstract: LEAD: After a four-month trial, an Israeli military court today convicted an American professor in the West Bank of disturbing the peace by taking part in an unauthorized Arab demonstration.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * General Electric Co. said its two microelectronics centers, now in Research Triangle Park, N.C., and Somerville, N.J., would be consolidated at the Research Triangle Park site, with 20 to 40 of the 250 Somerville employees transferred there.

headline: Soviet Planes Off Florida
abstract: LEAD: Four Soviet warplanes have been intercepted by Florida Air National Guard jets in the last week as they flew over international water, officials said today. An intercept is visual contact with aircraft that enter without notice into the United States air-defense identification zone, which extends 300 miles out.

headline: ADVERTISING; Dial Account Awarded
abstract: LEAD: Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson announced yesterday that it had obtained an unnamed assignment from the personal care division of the Dial Corporation. Ordinarily such an item wouldn't be worth so much space, but one remembers that the big Bristol-Myers, American Tobacco and Thomson Medical accounts at the agency started out the very same way, with the agency's foot in the door.

headline: Dollar Mostly Higher; Dealers Unimpressed
abstract: LEAD: The dollar ended mostly higher in comparatively light volume in world currency markets yesterday.

headline: A Speech About Europe Stirs Visions of Growth
abstract: LEAD: A particularly well-received speech at last week's meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in Boca Raton, Fla., was given by Armand de Malherbe of Ted Bates France, who is president of the European Association of Advertising Agencies.

headline: DEEP-POCKETED DEAL MAKERS
abstract: LEAD: The Borg-Warner Corporation last Friday acted like any other company under siege by an unwanted suitor: It turned to a major investment bank for help, in this case Merrill Lynch & Company.

headline: RIVALS SAY MACHINES ARE NO 'CLONE KILLERS'
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation's competitors in the personal computer industry, who had been bracing for the worst, breathed a slight sigh of relief today.

headline: DOW DROPS 10.93
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell a bit in some of the slowest trading of the year yesterday, leaving analysts divided over just what tune Wall Street is singing these days.

headline: Dollar Is Down Sharply On Volker Resignation
abstract: LEAD: The dollar plunged and precious metals soared yesterday on the news that Paul A. Volcker would not serve a third term as the Fed's chairman.

headline: Vietnam Stresses Oil
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam, which shipped its first oil exports only last month, plans to have its oil industry fuel development of the national economy, the Communist Party leader, Nguyen Van Linh, said today. The Hanoi radio reported that he had told oil workers that production of crude this year should be seven times the 40,500 tons of the second half of 1986.

headline: Merger at Union Pacific
abstract: LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation will combine two subsidiaries, Champlin Petroleum and the Rocky Mountain Energy Company, into a single operating concern called the Union Pacific Resources Company, Union Pacific announced on Thursday. It said the change would permit further cost and productivity improvements in the natural resource businesses.

headline: Brazil Acting to Halt New Trafficking in Cocaine
abstract: LEAD: South American drug trafficking rings, attracted by the availability of vital chemicals and by good airline connections to the north, are increasingly using Brazil as a processing and distribution point for cocaine, Brazilian and foreign narcotics experts say.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1987
abstract: LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The U.S. semiconductor industry appears to be rebounding, according to industry executives and analysts. The success of the Reagan Administration's trade sanctions against Japan and a sudden surge in purchases of personal computers have spurred demand and driven up profit margins.

headline: BURLINGTON HOSTILE BID IS RAISED
abstract: LEAD: An investor group led by Asher B. Edelman yesterday raised its hostile offer for Burlington Industries to $72 a share, from $67.

headline: Japan May Miss Quota
abstract: LEAD: Japanese auto makers may fall short of selling their 2.3-million-car allotment in the United States this year, Automotive News said today. The weekly industry journal said the Japanese auto makers' sales had been hurt by the strength of the yen against the dollar, growing supplies of Japanese-designed cars built in the United

headline: INTEREST RATES DROP MODESTLY
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday as the Treasury sold $10 billion of three-year notes, the first of three note and bond auctions this week.

headline: GORBACHEV ASSAILS 2 AIDES HE NAMED
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev coupled his call today for sweeping economic changes with a sharp attack, by name, on some of his leading economic planners and industrial ministers.

headline: QADDAFI IS FACING UNHAPPY COUNTRY
abstract: LEAD: A year after the American raid on Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have taken more power into his own hands but faces a nation unhappy with his costly defeat in Chad and economic chaos at home, according to diplomats here.

headline: FROM TAMIL REFUGEES, TALES OF SRI LANKA TORTURE
abstract: LEAD: The husky young refugee made a trigger motion with his right forefinger, indicating the finger that he said he saw government soldiers maim on healthy Tamil men back home in Sri Lanka.

headline: THE TESTIMONY SUGGESTS HIGH OFFICIALS REJECTED THE LAWS ON COVERT ACTIONS
abstract: LEAD: Out of the welter of details about Swiss bank accounts and arms shipments, one theme has emerged from the Congressional testimony of Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord: Some high Reagan Administration officials fostered a private, clandestine intelligence service for operations that the Government was unable or unwilling to undertake.

headline: U.S. Chides Greece on Terror Group
abstract: LEAD: A dispute developed today between Athens and Washington over United States intelligence reports saying that Athens had, for several months, conducted negotiations with the terrorist known as Abu Nidal. Greece rejected the assertions.  The United States intelligence reports were presented at a meeting here Thursday between the Greek Foreign Minister, Karolos Papoulias, and the United States Ambassador, Robert

headline: Baker Hughes Inc.
abstract: LEAD: The Baker International Corporation and the Hughes Tool Company said that they had agreed to a Department of Justice consent decree and had completed their previously announced merger. The newly formed company, Baker Hughes Inc., with headquarters in Houston, will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday under its symbol, BHI, the company said.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''While we may not be in a recession, the economy is not very buoyant.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 13, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: HERTZ NAMES PRESIDENT
abstract: LEAD: The Hertz Corporation, a unit of the Allegis Corporation, said yesterday that Craig R. Koch, general manager of the domestic rent-a-car division, had been named president and chief operating officer of Hertz. The polition of president had been vacant since 1983. Frank A. Olson continues as chairman and chief executive of the New York-based company.

headline: Ex-Libya Ambassador Hurt in Vienna Attack
abstract: LEAD: A former aide of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, was injured today in an attack during which a shot was fired, an Interior Ministry spokesman said.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: LEAD: ''We are talking about a medical disaster, a catastrophe of major magnitude, no matter what we do now, no matter what vaccines are developed in the next four years.''  - Health Commissioner David Axelrod of New York State, on the outlook for AIDS in the state.  [ A1:2. ]

headline: Darman to Depart For Shearson Post
abstract: LEAD: Deputy Treasury Secretary Richard G. Darman, a behind-the-scenes architect and strategist for many of President Reagan's biggest economic policy initiatives, is resigning to become a managing director and investment banker at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., the White House announced yesterday.

headline: Boliden-Allis Deal
abstract: LEAD: Boliden A.B., the Swedish mining and metals group, said it would buy the mining machinery division of the Allis-Chalmers Corporation for 600 million kronor, or about $90 million. The move is part of a restructuring announced by Allis-Chalmers March 4. Allis-Chalmers, which is based in Milwaukee, said it did not expect any material gain or loss from the sale of the division, which employs 4,300.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * British Telecommunications P.L.C., London, said it would begin to market electronic data transmission equipment of its own design in North America.

headline: 3 Latin American Leaders Issue Appeal on Debt
abstract: LEAD: The Presidents of Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay have appealed to the industrial powers to seek a way to lower interest rates on the foreign debts of developing countries during the meeting of major non-Communist industrial countries in Venice.

headline: Paine Webber Indictments
abstract: LEAD: A Federal grand jury indicted two more executives of Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday in connection with what was characterized as a $700,000 money-laundering scheme. The executives - Joseph

headline: Canadian Joblessness Off
abstract: LEAD: Canada's April unemployment rate fell to 9.3 percent after holding at 9.6 percent for two months, Statistics Canada said today. The unemployment rate was 9.6 percent in April 1986. The Government agency said the number of employed in April, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose 50,000 from the previous month to 11.85 million.

headline: OPPOSITION IN SEOUL REJECTS OFFER BY CHUN AIMED AT ENDING CRISIS
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's main opposition party rejected an offer Wednesday from President Chun Doo Hwan to reopen discussions on the critical issue of constitutional change.

headline: Goldome Shift Wins Approval
abstract: LEAD: State banking regulators today approved Goldome's proposal to change from a Federal to a New York bank charter, clearing the way for the bank, the nation's largest mutual savings institution, to convert to public ownership.

headline: Grand Jury Date For Crown Unit
abstract: LEAD: Crown Brands Inc. said that representatives of its I. Rokeach & Sons subsidiary were scheduled to appear next Monday before a grand jury in Federal District Court in New Jersey as part of ''an ongoing investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice into possible unfair competition practices relating to the kosher food industry.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co. has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a $200 million offering of debt securities.

headline: WEINBERGER URGES BASES IN GULF AREA FOR U.S. AIR PATROL
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf should provide bases and other support for aircraft that would patrol the waterway, protecting oil tankers and their naval escorts.

headline: COLONEL RECOUNTS HOW NORTH RAN CONTRA OPERATION >
abstract: LEAD: A former Air Force colonel described in detail today how Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North directed the secret aerial supply of munitions for the Nicaraguan rebels at a time when the program was dogged by almost comical problems.

headline: Rubbermaid Losing Passed-Over Officer
abstract: LEAD: Robert E. Fowler Jr., president and chief operating officer at Rubbermaid Inc., believed that he was in line to succeed his boss, Stanley C. Gault, as chairman and chief executive officer. But Mr. Gault told him that was not to be and Mr. Fowler has announced plans to leave the company by the end of the year.

headline: HIGH-FLYING THRIFT UNIT'S FALL
abstract: LEAD: The suites at the Bristol Hotel in Paris were superb, the foie gras in southwestern France was divine, lunch in Lyons was glorious. Truly, Dana Dixon wrote later, the two-week tour in 1983 was a dream trip.

headline: A War That None Can Afford to Win
abstract: LEAD: SEVERAL weeks ago, Art Buchwald suggested that Japanese executives be sent en masse to the Harvard Business School. There they would unlearn all they know about manufacturing and receive instruction in how to focus on the next quarterly dividend. In no time at all, Japanese productivity would deteriorate, trade surpluses would vanish and we would all be friends again.

headline: First Jersey Given Penalty
abstract: LEAD: First Jersey Securities Inc. and its Atlanta branch manager have agreed to pay $97,500 in penalties and cost reimbursements, concluding a state investigation into purported securities violations. Georgia's Secretary of State, Max Cleland, said Wednesday that the consent order signed by the branch manager, Matthew Wochele, and the New York-based stock brokerage firm also placed the company under probation for two years in Georgia.

headline: Vietnam's Newest Bank
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam's first commercial bank under Communist rule is scheduled to open next month, and one of its goals will be to help check inflation, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported today. It quoted Nguyen Xuan Oanh, an economic adviser to the new premier, Pham Hung, as saying the bank would open in early July in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon.

headline: RJR Nabisco Sells 4 Pipe Tobaccos
abstract: LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it had sold its Prince Albert, Carter Hall, Apple and Royal Comfort pipe-tobacco brands to John Middleton Inc., a family-owned tobacco concern in Pennsylvania. Terms were not dislcosed.

headline: CONTRA CHIEF SAYS HE GAVE $50,000 IN EFFORT TO FREE U.S. HOSTAGES
abstract: LEAD: The leader of the largest organization of Nicaraguan rebels said today that he gave a White House official $50,000 in mid-1985 to finance a private effort to free the American hostages in Lebanon.

headline: DOW TUMBLES BY 37.38 ON CITICORP RUMORS
abstract: LEAD: The stock market was battered yesterday by rumors that Citicorp would restructure its portfolio of loans to developing nations and by fears of higher interest rates.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Centerior Energy Corp., Cleveland, elected Lyman C. Phillips executive vice president.

headline: A WAYFARER IS TRUNDLING HOME TO GLORY
abstract: LEAD: High in the Cascade Mountains, where the road rises and falls steeply between rushing alpine streams, tourists have been lining up to cheer on a young man propelling himself westward in a wheelchair.

headline: EX-U.S. ENVOY SAYS HE WAS ORDERED TO ASSIST CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: A former United States Ambassador to Costa Rica, who has been accused of improperly helping the rebels in Nicaragua, testified today that he was operating under direct orders from the National Security Council, the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Cheap Shot?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: GATT, Denouncing U.S. Oil Tax, Seeks Change
abstract: LEAD: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said yesterday that a United States tax on petroleum violated its rules and it urged the Reagan Administration to change the tax.

headline: JAPANESE BOND PLAN DISAPPOINTS FIRMS
abstract: LEAD: The Japanese Government's recently announced measures to improve foreign firms' access to Japanese financial markets fall short of American firms' hopes, according to several here.

headline: THREAT FROM CHRISTIAN MILITIA KEEPS BEIRUT AIRPORT CLOSED
abstract: LEAD: Attempts this weekend to reopen the Beirut airport, closed for two months, have turned into a national controversy and heightened tensions between Moslems and Christians.

headline: TEXT OF ECONOMIC DECLARATION BY 7 LEADING INDUSTRIAL NATIONS
abstract: LEAD: Following is the official text of the economic declaration issued today at the end of the summit conference of the seven leading industrialized democracies:  Introduction

headline: Britons To Acquire Ammirati
abstract: LEAD: NOW it is Ammirati & Puris, one of the most talked about medium-size agencies, that is being acquired by a publicly held British ad agency holding company, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership.

headline: Santa Fe Head Finds Tasks More Difficult
abstract: LEAD: John S. Reed, chairman and chief executive of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, has a load of worries.

headline: BID TO BUY BURLINGTON FINANCED
abstract: LEAD: An international banking group headed by the First National Bank of Chicago and the Royal Bank of Canada has joined Shearson Lehman Brothers in raising $2 billion in cash to finance the tender offer for Burlington Industries, documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

headline: Texaco Bonds Drop Sharply
abstract: LEAD: In the bond market, where worries about the Pennzoil Company's lawsuit had already reduced prices of the bonds of Texaco Inc., the Supreme Court ruling yesterday led to another sharp drop in Texaco issues.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aca Joe Inc., San Francisco, said its accountant, Touche, Ross & Co., intended to qualify its report on Aca Joe's year ended Jan. 31 because of uncertainty about the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

headline: G.M.'S PLAN FOR SATURN: FEW SELLERS, MORE PROFIT
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is expected to announce next week that it will try a marketing strategy pioneered by Honda, Hyundai and other automobile importers when it begins naming dealers for cars produced by its Saturn Corporation, people familiar with its plans said.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: Yesterday with scarcity of new tax-exempt issues on the calendar and rates in the municipal market holding at about the same as levels the previous day, New Jersey brought to market a $299 million issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank. Last week some major sales were postponed because of extremely volatile market conditions.

headline: REAGAN URGES A RISE IN DEBT CEILING
abstract: LEAD: Warning of dire financial consequences, the White House urged Congress today to raise the national debt ceiling before the Government runs out of authority to borrow money this Friday.

headline: PATENTS; Electrical Fracture Treatment
abstract: LEAD: AN apparatus for applying electricity to the body in order to stimulate the repair or growth of bones was patented this week by Sheldon Thaler of Princeton, N.J. Mr. Thaler, who plans to grant licenses for the apparatus, is vice president of Geomed Inc., a medical products company in Middlesex, N.J.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN THE TENNIS BUSINESS
abstract: LEAD: THE Game Plan study served some sobering statistics to the Tennis Industry Council. Of the country's 10.5 million to 11 million players, only 1.6 million -about 15 percent - are serious players and active consumers of tennis goods and services. Sixty-three percent of all players are playing less. And the report predicted that unless the industry took action, the total number of players would continue to drop significantly.

headline: G.E. Unit Is Issuer Of Yen Warrants
abstract: LEAD: Bear, Stearns & Company announced yesterday that it had sold two million ''currency exchange warrants,'' or C.E.W.'s, at $4.50 per warrant, each giving an investor the right to buy $50 worth of yen at a rate of 149.70 to the dollar.

headline: EBB IN TAKEOVERS FORSEEN
abstract: LEAD: A Supreme Court decision upholding an Indiana curb on takeovers could bring a sharp drop in hostile takeover activity, experts on mergers predicted yesterday.

headline: BAKER PLAN FAULTED AT O.E.C.D.
abstract: LEAD: A special study has found that the policies of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and those devised by Japan and West Germany in response to his appeals would do next to nothing to improve the world economy, according to officials familiar with the work.

headline: CENTERIOR TO SELL STAKE FOR $1 BILLION
abstract: LEAD: The Centerior Energy Corporation announced a refinancing program today in which it would sell its stake in two energy plants to an unidentified group for about $1 billion and then lease the power.

headline: Cuba Sends 20 Ex-Prisoners To U.S. at Rate of 2 a Week
abstract: LEAD: Cuba has allowed 20 former political prisoners to emigrate to the United States in the last 10 weeks at the rate of two a week, United States officials say.

headline: FIJI COLONEL NAMES GOVERNMENT, BUT CONTROL OF ISLANDS IS IN DOUBT
abstract: LEAD: The army colonel who led a bloodless coup here named a new government today, but the Governor General, an influential chief, said he had assumed executive power.

headline: Genentech Is Set Back By F.D.A. Panel's Ruling
abstract: LEAD: Genentech Inc., the closely followed biotechnology company, suffered a blow on Friday when an advisory committee of the Federal Drug Administration recommended that the agency not approve the company's long-awaited drug, T.P.A., for use in treating victims of heart attacks.

headline: 380 MILES FROM LYONS, A QUIETER TRIAL
abstract: LEAD: Three hundred and eighty miles away in Lyons, Klaus Barbie, the city's erstwhile Gestapo chief, finds himself at the center of the world's attention.

headline: Budapest Officially Dedicates A Mounument to Wallenberg
abstract: LEAD: A monument to Raoul Wallenberg was officially dedicated Friday, nearly 40 years after an earlier statue was mysteriously removed on the eve of its dedication.

headline: BUGGY WHIPS OF THE INFORMATION AGE
abstract: LEAD: THE skunk cabbage was peeking through last year's matted brown leaves and coltsfoot bloomed in the meadow. In the space of 24 hours, nature had shrugged off winter and announced that, yes, finally spring had arrived. This was no day to hang around computers. Better to go riding. I popped off to the tack shop to replace a broken set of reins neglected over the dreary winter months.

headline: Rating Reviewed For BCI Holdings
abstract: LEAD: The rating on $3.5 billion of outstanding debt issued by the BCI Holdings Corporation is under review for possible upgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced late Wednesday.

headline: Dow Up 11.36 as Stocks Are Mixed
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average fell at the rate of one point a minute during much of the first half-hour of trading yesterday, but the shock of the increase in banks' prime lending rate quickly wore off, and stock prices were mixed at the close.

headline: Vatican Cash Crisis Is Viewed as Forcing Changes on Church
abstract: LEAD: Basic changes in the institutional character of the Roman Catholic Church may be required to resolve a deepening financial crisis at the Vatican, officials say.

headline: HOUSE PANEL BACKS $5 BILLION RESCUE OF F.S.L.I.C.
abstract: LEAD: The House Banking Committee voted today to raise $5 billion over the next two years to help the ailing Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which Government auditors say is technically insolvent.

headline: Italian Premier Resigns
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi resigned tonight, a move widely expected after Christian Democratic ministers withdrew from his Cabinet on Wednesday. Mr. Craxi handed his resignation to President Francesco Cossiga after a debate in the Chamber of Deputies. Mr. Cossiga is expected to appoint an interim government to administer affairs until early elections can be held, probably in June.

headline: JAPANESE MANEUVERING FOR SUCCESSION
abstract: LEAD: Although Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's term does not end for five months, a struggle to succeed him is already under way, and it may alter power lineups within Japan's ruling party.

headline: Miller & Rhoads
abstract: LEAD: The Allied Stores Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Miller & Rhoads division to an investor group led by the division's managers and by Kevin F. Donohoe, a Philadelphia real estate investor. Miller & Rhoads operates 21 stores in North Carolina and its home state of Virginia. The price was not disclosed.

headline: Sabena and S.A.S. In Merger Talks
abstract: LEAD: Sabena, the Belgian state carrier, said it had agreed to discuss a merger of flight operations with Scandinavian Airline Systems, which could create one of Europe's biggest airlines. Aviation industry officials said the merger talks were prompted by increased international competition and a move toward air deregulation in the European

headline: Laborite Puts Up a Fight in British Campaign
abstract: LEAD: If political campaigns were judged like prizefights, the combative Neil Kinnock might well be ahead on points as Britain prepares to vote on Thursday.

headline: Caesars World Adds to Offer
abstract: LEAD: Caesars World Inc. as part of its continuing efforts to keep the company independent, raised the cash portion of its recapitalization plan from $25 to $26.25 yesterday. As before, investors will also own a new share in the recapitalized company.

headline: Consumers Power Debt Reviewed
abstract: LEAD: The rating for about $2.9 billion of the Consumers Power Company's outstanding debt is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's announced yesterday.

headline: South Africa Frees 269 Detainees Under Age 16
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government said today that it had released 269 of the 280 children under the age of 16 who were being detained under the 11-month-old state of emergency decree.

headline: INVESTING; NEOAX EMERGES FROM OBSCURITY
abstract: LEAD: The name Neoax Inc. is not well known, except to students of bankruptcies. For almost 70 years, the company called itself the White Motor Corporation and then, after a stint in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, was reorganized in late 1983 as Northeast Ohio Axle Inc. That was condensed in May 1986 to Neoax. Its stock, which trades over-the-counter, sagged to $2.75 in

headline: Miwok Capital Files With S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by the Miwok Capital Corporation, which controls a 10.6 percent stake in the Zondervan Corporation, said it was seeking ''other persons interested in acquiring control'' of the Bible publisher, based in Grand Rapids, Mich.

headline: THATCHER'S WEALTHIEST CRITIC
abstract: LEAD: David Sainsbury, one of Britain's most respected business executives and one of its wealthiest individuals, is precisely the type of person expected to be applauding Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-enterprise vision of the nation's future and supporting her Conservative Government in next month's general election.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The TNE Funding Corporation, a subsidiary of New England Mutual Life Insurance, is offering $250 million of 9 percent guaranteed notes due 1995 at a price of par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON SECURITY AT MOSCOW EMBASSY
abstract: LEAD: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington on security concerns at the American Embassy buildings in Moscow:  OPENING STATEMENT

headline: GENERAL UNDER ATTACK: THE QUESTIONS SHARPEN
abstract: LEAD: For two days, Richard V. Secord - United States Military Academy '55, Naval War College '72, a veteran of more than 250 combat missions in Southeast Asia, a retired Air Force major general - rattled off facts and figures about the work he did to support the Reagan Administration's policies in Iran and

headline: Israeli Accord Reported Near On a New Envoy for the U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Ambassador to Mexico, Moshe Arad, has been summoned to Jerusalem to be interviewed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir about possibly becoming Ambassador to the United States, Government officials said today.

headline: MOSCOW OFFERING TO PUT OFF A BAN ON ATOM TESTING
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union, in a shift, has offered to postpone its demand for a total nuclear test ban and to concentrate first on intermediate testing limitations.

headline: Six Killed When Small Plane Crashes Off Coast of Antigua
abstract: LEAD: A small plane crashed in the Atlantic Ocean today shortly after takeoff from the island of Antigua, killing all six people aboard, the police said.

headline: SOVIET CHARGES U.S. WITH BUGGING
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union struck back today in the embassy bugging dispute, displaying an array of devices described as eavesdropping equipment planted by American agents at Soviet diplomatic missions in the United States.

headline: REAGAN SEEKS NEW U.N. PUSH IN GULF
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will seek support at the economic summit meeting here for a United Nations resolution threatening Iran and Iraq with an arms embargo if they refuse negotiations to end their war, White House officials said today.

headline: Wyman and Beech Get New Leaders
abstract: LEAD: James S. Walsh, president and chief executive officer of the Raytheon Company's Beech Aircraft Corporation subsidiary in Wichita, Kan., has been named president and chief executive officer of the Wyman-Gordon Company.

headline: Business and the Law; Delaware Plan On Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: Delaware, which is to corporate law what Switzerland is to banking secrecy, will soon have new rules governing takeovers, according to lawyers and legislators.

headline: Continental's Bid For General Tire
abstract: LEAD: Continental Gummi-Werke A.G., West Germany's largest tire maker, said it is raising about $319 million to make a bid for the tire operations of Gencorp. Shareholders approved an increase of 130 million marks, or $71.5 million, in its authorized capital, as well as a new issue of stock warrants and convertible bonds worth up to 450 million marks, or $247.5 million.

headline: Magazine Is Planned For the Handicapped
abstract: LEAD: Equal Opportunity Publications of Greenlawn, L.I., publisher of six special-market career publications, is bringing out a seventh in September called Independent Living, a life-style magazine for the handicapped.

headline: Contra Chief Explains Checks
abstract: LEAD: Adolfo Calero, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, has said that he provided $2,500 in traveler's checks directly to a rebel supporter who has represented himself to Congress as a Roman Catholic priest.

headline: 'REVERSE LBO'S' BRING RICHES
abstract: LEAD: When the Rockefeller family decided it no longer wanted to own Outlet Communications, a broadcast company based in Providence, R.I., some of Outlet's executives took it off the Rockefellers' hands - and put millions into their own pockets.

headline: Chile's Right-Wing President Welcomes a Chinese Official
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who often speaks out on his role in fighting to defeat Communism in Chile, warmly received the Chinese Foreign Minister today and gave a lunch in his honor.

headline: Argentina Extends Immunity In 'Dirty War' Rights Abuses
abstract: LEAD: The House of Deputies gave final approval early today to a bill that would end prosecution of most military officers accused of rights abuses in the ''dirty war'' against leftists in the 1970's.

headline: Uncertainty on Horizon as Italians Vote Today
abstract: LEAD: Italians will vote Sunday in a parliamentary election that many people predict will open a period of uncertainty and shifting coalitions after almost four years of stability under the Socialist-led Government of Bettino Craxi.

headline: Morgan Stanley's Man Behind Burlington Deal
abstract: LEAD: Alan E. Goldberg is not afraid of big numbers. At age 32, he has been put in a top position at Morgan Stanley, putting together billion-dollar deals.

headline: 4 Admit U.S. Charges In Plot on Indian Aide
abstract: LEAD: Four Sikhs pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in New Orleans to conspiring to assassinate Bhajan Lal, Chief Minister of the Indian state of Haryana, while he was in New Orleans for eye surgery in 1985.

headline: House Votes to Delay Soviet Use of New Embassy
abstract: LEAD: The House of Representatives voted today to prohibit the Soviet Union from occupying its new embassy complex here until President Reagan has certified that the new United States Embassy in Moscow is secure and that the Russians are not using their site on a Washington hilltop for electronic espionage.

headline: PALL OVER THE ROBOTICS SHOW
abstract: LEAD: It might be remembered as a haunted trade show. The ghosts that hovered over last week's Robotics Industry Association exhibition were those of absent companies who in years past never dreamed of missing the annual conclave.

headline: THE SENATE VOTES THRIFT AID AGAIN
abstract: LEAD: For the second time in two months, the Senate today passed a legislative package that would inject $7.5 billion in new money over the next two years into the insolvent fund that insures $900 billion of deposits at the nation's 3,200 thrift institutions. Today's vote was 93 to 3.

headline: DIM HOPES FOR SUMMIT TALKS
abstract: LEAD: The seven-nation industrial summit conference that President Reagan will attend next month in Venice is likely to prove unusually modest in its achievements despite the long agenda of issues, analysts and officials report.

headline: New Moody's Bond Index
abstract: LEAD: Moody's Investors Service yesterday introduced a new index of corporate bonds that it hopes will eventually become the basis for a new futures contract on the Commodity Exchange.

headline: Sri Lanka-I.M.F. Talks
abstract: LEAD: Sri Lanka and the International Monetary Fund have broadly agreed on economic reforms, but tough negotiations will be necessary to win approval of loans of $240 million, a Government official said today. A senior official of the Finance and Planning Ministry said an I.M.F.-World Bank team would be in Colombo next month to start talks on details of a three-year reform of the island's economy.

headline: By ISADORE BARMASH
abstract: LEAD: Come tomorrow morning, thousands of dear old dads will be beaming on the outside but grimacing on the inside as they open that all-too-familiar thin, rectangular box. Not another ugly tie!

headline: HOLLYWOOD SPINS A NEW FAIRY TALE
abstract: LEAD: HOLLYWOOD, which has conceived so many wonderful stories over the years, is spinning another beauty about the cable television industry. According to the studios, cable is fast becoming an unrestrained monopoly, intent on gouging consumers and, yes, the companies that make films and other programming.

headline: Funds Resisted For Sematech
abstract: LEAD: The Commerce Department opposes a Federal subsidy for an American semiconductor industry venture for sophisticated electronics research, Lew Cramer, Acting Deputy Assistant Commerce Secretary, said today. Mr. Cramer told a House

headline: BOEING GETS BIG STAKE IN ALLEGIS
abstract: LEAD: United Airlines announced yesterday a $2.1 billion airplane deal aimed at protecting the carrier and its parent company, the Allegis Corporation, from a hostile takeover.

headline: Bahamian Premier Is Re-Elected; Aide Says U.S. Meddled in Vote
abstract: LEAD: The deputy leader of the political party that has ruled the Bahamas for 20 years and that has been widely accused of corruption, declared victory in national elections tonight, giving Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling a sixth term in office.

headline: SOUTH KOREA CRACKDOWN: COURTING NEW COLLISIONS
abstract: LEAD: By abruptly shutting off public discussion on altering South Korea's basic electoral structure, President Chun Doo Hwan has increased the chances that he and the opposition will collide head-on.

headline: C.I.A. ACCUSED OF MANILA ROLE
abstract: LEAD: An American fact-finding mission led by Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, charged today that the Central Intelligence Agency was behind the rise of vigilante groups opposed to the Communist insurgency in the Philippines.

headline: Mitel Leader Moves To Chairman's Post
abstract: LEAD: The Mitel Corporation, a major Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, is looking for a new president and chief executive.

headline: OFFER BY KOREAN IS PRAISED BY U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration today praised the proposal by a South Korean leader for a range of political reforms.

headline: Simmons Beautyrest Goes With Bates Unit
abstract: LEAD: An $8 million budget for advertising a mattress is nothing to snore at, especially at Simmons U.S.A. in Atlanta.

headline: TV Series Highlights Ad Efforts
abstract: LEAD: MARSHALL PENGRA is a second-generation broadcaster who also spent 20 years in the agency business. Who better to produce and be host of a TV series on advertising?

headline: POLITICAL GOALS SPUR BOTH U.S. AND SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union seem to be inching toward a summit meeting in Washington this autumn, provided they can resolve their final disagreements over a treaty eliminating short-range and medium-range nuclear weapons from Europe.

headline: NORTH'S SECRETARY DESCRIBES EFFORT TO HIDE EVIDENCE
abstract: LEAD: Fawn Hall, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's secretary at the National Security Council, testified today that she had altered some sensitive documents, destroyed others and smuggled still others off the White House grounds last fall in seeking to protect Colonel North.

headline: Dow Rises 17.43 Points; Light Trading Reported
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average gained a quiet 17.43 points yesterday, closing at 2,243.20, in light pre-holiday trading.

headline: FARMERS IN JAPAN AGREE TO A RICE SUBSIDY CUT
abstract: LEAD: With Japan's protectionist agricultural policies under attack at home and abroad, the nation's most powerful farmers' group has agreed to accept a cut in rice subsidies for the first time in 31 years.

headline: The U.N. Today: June 11, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Investor Reduces Rorer Holdings
abstract: LEAD: The British investor Alan E. Clore has lowered his stake in Rorer Group Inc. to 12.3 percent, from 15.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore gave no reason for the sale of the Rorer shares. When Mr. Clore began to buy Rorer shares in the fall of 1985, he said the purchases were for investment purposes only.

headline: Westland Job Cuts
abstract: LEAD: Westland, the British helicopter company that an American-led consortium saved from bankruptcy last year, will cut 1,155 jobs at its Yeovil factory in the west of England, a company spokesman said. ''We had to make capacity reductions in view of the market situation of helicopter manufacturing capacity,'' he said.

headline: JAPAN LETS 4 U.S. BANKS UNDERWRITE SECURITIES
abstract: LEAD: Japan said yesterday that it would permit four major American commercial banks to establish securities underwriting and trading operations in Tokyo.

headline: Communications Venture for Fiat
abstract: LEAD: The car maker Fiat S.p.A. and another Italian concern are close to forming a joint venture that could make Italy a competitive international force in telecommunications. The venture would be between Telettra, a subsidiary of Fiat, and the state-owned telecommunications group Italtel. To be called Telit S.p.A., it would quickly seek an alliance with larger companies, Milan analysts said.

headline: LATE APRIL AUTO SALES STRENGTHEN
abstract: LEAD: Automobile sales grew stronger in the final 10 days of April, finishing three-tenths of 1 percent below an unusually strong 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. Sales of domestic light trucks were brisk as well, gaining seven-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: American to Direct Jardine Matheson
abstract: LEAD: The Jardine Matheson group, one of the oldest and biggest trading companies in Asia, yesterday named an American lawyer as its managing director.

headline: NEW COMPLICATIONS LOOM FOR LATIN BORROWERS
abstract: LEAD: Government officials, bankers and diplomats across Latin America said today that Citicorp's decision to add $3 billion to its reserves as protection against weak loans was certain to complicate the process of obtaining the new money that Latin American debtors will soon require.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
abstract: LEAD: PASSING muster with a ''mashgiah,'' a rabbi from one of the several dozen agencies that certify products as kosher, is no piece of cake. ''It's like having another Food and Drug Administration down your back,'' conceded Ms. Spear of the Orthodox Union, which certifies an estimated 80 percent of the kosher products on the market.

headline: Advertising; Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Sims & Associates, a public relations firm, has been established by Idan Sims.

headline: Advertising; Media Man Stresses Negotiation
abstract: LEAD: AFTER 32 years at Young & Rubicam, many of them as head of the media operation, Joseph W. Ostrow is now ensconced a couple of blocks away at FCB/Leber Katz Partners. He is both media director for that agency and, as an executive vice president, worldwide media czar for Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * C. Ray Freeman has been promoted to executive vice president at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.

headline: Meese Given New Evidence On Waldheim's War Record
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit has given Attorney General Edwin Meese 2d new evidence on the wartime record of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to bolster its recommendation that he be barred from the United States, Justice Department officials said today.

headline: HISTORIC LOOK IS STRESSED IN A PARK SLOPE RENEWAL
abstract: LEAD: Developers frequently complain that the restrictions imposed by preservation agencies on rehabilitations of properties in historic districts are expensive and meddlesome.

headline: South Korean Stocks Plunge
abstract: LEAD: The South Korean stock market fell sharply today on news of Government plans to curb the boom that has pushed the share index up by more than 50 percent this year.

headline: Agreement to End Coastal Dispute
abstract: LEAD: The Coastal Corporation and the TransAmerican Natural Gas Corporation have proposed settling more than $4 billion in lawsuits with an agreement for gas sales and transportation between the two Texas concerns, a lawyer for Coastal said.

headline: Davis Mining Bids For Becor Western
abstract: LEAD: Becor Western Inc. said it had received a buyout bid, worth about $173.3 million in cash and notes, from Davis Mining and Manufacturing Inc. of Coeburn, Va. Becor said Davis had proposed to buy its common shares outstanding for $10.45 in cash plus $3 principal amount of a 12.5 percent debenture. In addition,

headline: ALLIANCES, NOT ISSUES, IN ITALY'S RACE
abstract: LEAD: Kicking off the Christian Democrats' campaign in this city last week, the party secretary, Ciriaco De Mita, issued a dramatic warning. ''The alternative is around the corner,'' he said in a loud threatening voice.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD:  Olympic Uncertainties

headline: U.S. EXPECTING TO SEND LARGE CRUISERS TO GULF
abstract: LEAD: Despite advice from naval commanders in the Persian Gulf that relatively small frigates are ideal for escorting merchant vessels, the Pentagon is likely to send larger, more sophisticated cruisers there, according to Government officials familiar with planning for the operation.

headline: Finnish Regime Wins a Test
abstract: LEAD: Finland's six-week-old coalition Government survived a no-confidence motion today by a 121-20 vote in Parliament. The Communist-run People's Democratic League accused the Cabinet of Prime Minister Harri Holkeri of indifference to layoffs in industry and also of neglecting trade with the Soviet Union.

headline: 104 More Bodies Retrieved From British Ferry
abstract: LEAD: The known death toll from last month's sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise rose to 165 today after divers retrieved 104 more bodies trapped amid debris in the vessel's upper decks.

headline: Bond Prices Swing Upward
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices rose yesterday in response to stability in the dollar and a drop in commodities prices.

headline: New Petersen Magazine
abstract: LEAD: Super/Moto Cross is the latest magazine title being offered by the Petersen Publishing Company, the leisure time specialists of Los Angeles. The magazine, to be published six times a year, joins Motorcyclist and Dirt Rider in the Petersen stable. It will cover the fields of motocross and cross-country racing.

headline: CONCERN ON BIG SUPPLY OF GASOLINE
abstract: LEAD: Concern over high gasoline inventories continued for a second day yesterday, as prices of crude oil and petroleum products moved slightly lower in brisk trading.

headline: General Cinema's Notes Yield 9.49%
abstract: LEAD: The General Cinema Corporation yesterday brought to market $125 million of 9 3/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1997 at a price to investors of 99.25, to yield 9.49 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: COUP HERO GUILTY IN PORTUGAL TRIAL
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, the hero of Portugal's 1974 revolution, was convicted today of leading a left-wing terrorist group that carried out robberies, bombings and political killings.

headline: The U.N. Today: May 7, 1987
abstract: LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10 A.M.

headline: Pay 'N Pak To Be Acquired
abstract: LEAD: Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc., brushing aside a sweetened bid from the investor Paul A. Bilzerian, agreed today to be acquired by a management-led group in a deal worth about $210 million.

headline: Singapore Trade Gain
abstract: LEAD: Singapore's trade deficit narrowed in April as exports rose sharply, the Trade Development Board said today. The deficit for the month came to $447 million, down from $641 million in March.

headline: IN WEST, AFTER ANXIETY, NO MAJOR TECHNICAL CHANGES IN INDUSTRY
abstract: LEAD: In the year since the Chernobyl disaster, nuclear power has undergone its most critical appraisal since the invention of the reactor in 1942. But despite the global anxiety created by the Soviet accident, experts say that it has not caused major technical changes in the nuclear power industry of the West.

headline: 3 in Financing Of Borg Deal
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had received commitments from three major banks for $3.4 billion in financing for its previously announced acquisition of the Borg-Warner Corporation.

headline: 6-Month Saatchi Profit Is More Than Doubled
abstract: LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi, the London-based communications holding company, has announced its financial results for the fiscal first half ended March 31. Last week the company reported revenues of $580 million, twice the $290 million of a year earlier. Net income more than doubled, to $49.3 million, from $20.4 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Computer Cost Cut
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Tele-graph Company, responding to price cuts in the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer line, said it would reduce the prices of its PC's by up to 38 percent. The cuts affect the A.T.& T. PC 6300, the PC 6310 and the PC 6300 Plus computers. For example, a 6300 with 640,000 bytes of internal memory and two floppy disk drives would cost $1,565, down from $2,020.

headline: LENGTHY TALKS PRECEDED U.S. - JAPAN RATE MOVES
abstract: LEAD: The complementary interest-rate moves disclosed today by the United States and Japan followed long discussions between the two nations' central banks during the last month, Federal Reserve and other monetary officials said today.

headline: Fistfights Reported at Polls As Maltese Pick Government
abstract: LEAD: Voters cast ballots today in the most fiercely contested election on this Mediterranean island since independence from Britain in 1964. All 65 seats in Parliament were at stake; results were not expected until Monday.
