headline: Oil Rig Count Up by 15
abstract: LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States this week totaled 765, up 15 from the previous week, the Hughes Tool Company reported today. The nationwide count totaled 750 last week, the Houston-based maker of oil tools said. The rig count, considered to be the baromoter of drilling activity, totaled 855 at this time last year.

headline: Beatrice Sets Public Offering of Spinoff Company
abstract: LEAD: The Beatrice Companies announced today that, as expected, it would spin off part of the company in a public offering.

headline: Court Backs Plan For Storage Tech
abstract: LEAD: The Storage Technology Corporation, a leading maker of I.B.M.-compatible data storage devices and printers, said its plan for reorganization and emergence from Chapter 11 protection had been approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Denver. Storage Tech, which is based in Louisville, Colo., filed for protection from its creditors in

headline: Patents; Magnetic Treatment Of Cancer
abstract: LEAD: AN inventor of various methods of treating diseases was granted a patent this week for a method of killing cancer cells without injuring adjacent normal cells. The treatment was done with magnetic particles that are heated by induction. The inventor, Dr. Robert T. Gordon, reports that laboratory trials of the method have proved successful.

headline: Norway Planning to Improve Conditions at Frontier Posts
abstract: LEAD: Norway's Defense Minister, Johan Jorgen Holst, said in a speech Tuesday that he would try to improve salaries and living conditions for 300 soldiers at monitoring stations on the Soviet border.

headline: Mauritius-Boeing Deal
abstract: LEAD: Air Mauritius has leased a second Boeing 747 SP jumbo jet and will take delivery of two Boeing 767-200 long-range airliners in 1988, the airline's general manager said today. The second-hand 747, which was acquired on a renewable one-year lease, made its first scheduled flight, to Munich, West Germany, earlier this month, he said.

headline: BUSINESS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 29, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: BARBIE IS A SPECTER IN A CABINET RIFT IN FRANCE
abstract: LEAD: With Klaus Barbie's trial in its second week, the former Gestapo official's name has been invoked in a dispute within France's governing conservative coalition.

headline: Durable Orders Rise 3.4%
abstract: LEAD: Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, powered by a jump in demand for military equipment, climbed 3.4 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: Hospital Corp.'s Stock Jumps $3.50
abstract: LEAD: Shares in the Hospital Corporation of America rose $3.50, to $41.625, in heavy New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday after the company received a $47-a-share takeover bid. The offer, valued at $3.8 billion, was from Charles R. Miller and Richard E. Ragsdale, two former officers of the Republic Health Corporation, and Richard L.

headline: The U.N. Today: April 9, 1987
abstract: LEAD: SECURITY COUNCIL

headline: INVESTING; Manville: No Place but Down?
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the Manville Corporation, the asbestos-plagued building products manufacturer that is exected to emerge from bankruptcy early next year, shot above $5 last week. The stock sold at $3 in late May and less than $2 in February. Caught in the surge - and involuntarily helping it along - were bearish traders who had sold short Manville shares in recent months, expecting a decline.

headline: Dow Rise of 1.42 Ends 4-Day Slide
abstract: LEAD: Stocks edged slightly higher yesterday, ending Wall Street's four-day slide.

headline: Contel's Chief Quits Over 'Differences'
abstract: LEAD: The Contel Corporation, which recently moved to cancel a merger with the Communications Satellite Corporation, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, John N. Lemasters, had resigned after ''differences in both management philosophy and operating policy.''

headline: U.S. Cautions South Korea
abstract: LEAD: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige warned South Korea today that it must open its markets to prevent a tougher American attitude from developing over a flood of imports.

headline: Earthquake Shakes Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: An earthquake shook the Tokyo area today, rattling buildings and interrupting train lines, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Meteorological Agency officials said the quake measured 5.3 on the Richter scale.

headline: Market Place; British Accent For New Fund
abstract: LEAD: WITHIN a few weeks, American residents will have their first opportunity to buy shares in a closed-end fund that will invest primarily in British companies.

headline: Takeover-Law Losses Seen
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that shareholders of Ohio-based companies lost more than $1.4 billion in the value of their stockholdings in the wake of a new state law passed last fall to discourage hostile takeovers.

headline: The U.N. Today: April 27, 1987
abstract: LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Preparatory Committee for Conference on Disarmament and Development - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Decolonization Subcommittee on Small Territories - 3 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL  Commission on Study of Economic and Social Fields - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: YUGOSLAVS PUT EXECUTION OFF
abstract: LEAD: The execution of Andrija Artukovic, a convicted Croatian war criminal who was extradited by the United States, has been postponed indefinitely because of poor health, legal sources said today.

headline: KIDDER AGREES TO PAY $25 MILLION TO SETTLE INSIDER TRADING CHARGES
abstract: LEAD: In a step that broadens the scope of the Wall Street scandals, Kidder, Peabody & Company agreed yesterday to pay a record $25.3 million to settle insider-trading charges.

headline: NORTHROP SEES LOSS ON BOMBER
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it would report a second-quarter loss because of a $124 million write-down that analysts said was caused by higher-than-expected costs on the classified Stealth bomber project.

headline: Maxicare Foils Embezzlement Try
abstract: LEAD: Maxicare Health Plan Inc. said it hads thwarted an attempt to embezzle nearly $7.6 million from the health maintenance organization company. It said that one man had been arrested in San Diego by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the case, and added that the suspect was not a Maxicare employee.

headline: G.M. Cites Need To Compete Better
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation believes it must become more competitive with other auto makers in the next five years or stop building cars in the United States, a senior G.M. official was quoted as saying. The Detroit Free Press quoted Alfred Warren, G.M.'s industrial relations vice president, as saying, ''We've got about three to five years to either get our act together or get out of the business.

headline: ATHEIST PREACHES GLASNOST, SO A PRIEST HAS HOPE
abstract: LEAD: The Rev. Gleb Yakunin, who was stripped of his priestly office, imprisoned and exiled to Siberia for protesting limits on religious freedom in the Soviet Union, has been reinstated by the Russian Orthodox Church in a move that promises to test the state of religious freedom under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: New York Fed Advisory Panel
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has formed an advisory committee consisting of top bankers and Wall Street executives to counsel the Fed on the evolution of the international capital markets.

headline: A Slow Modernization of India's Ancient Cart
abstract: LEAD: For centuries, the bullock cart has symbolized the face of traditional India and its ancient, village-based civilization to the outside world.

headline: Citicorp Auction Rates Up Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.7842 percent, up from 6.2415 percent last week.

headline: Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Country Home magazine will raise its circulation rate base 10 percent, to 880,000, and advertising rates 10 percent with the August issue.

headline: Added Element in Asia: Confucius
abstract: LEAD: As students take to the streets of South Korea, social campaigners go to jail in Singapore and politicians in China wrestle over a path to development, many East Asians are re-examining in an age of turbulence the clear-headed teachings of an ancient sage: Confucius.

headline: THIRD MARINE GUARD FROM U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW ARRESTED
abstract: LEAD: The Marine Corps has arrested a third enlisted man who served as a guard at the American Embassy in Moscow on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women, the Pentagon said today.

headline: ALLEGIS ADDING $3 BILLION OF DEBT TO SHIELD ITSELF AGAINST TAKEOVER
abstract: LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, which owns United Airlines, the Hertz car rental agency and major hotel chains, took a drastic step yesterday to avoid being taken over or broken up.

headline: Delta-Western Merger Allowed
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court, rejecting an emergency request by a Western Airlines union, refused to interfere with the $860 million merger of Western and Delta Air Lines. The court, without any recorded dissent, let stand an order issued last Wednesday by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that cleared the way for the merger.

headline: Milken Makes a Rare Appearance
abstract: LEAD: Michael R. Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s reclusive junk-bond chief, strayed briefly into the public eye today when he kicked off the firm's annual research conference with a brief address to some of the 2,500 institutional investors and corporate executives in attendance.

headline: UAL Meeting
abstract: LEAD: Richard J. Ferris, chairman of UAL Inc., scheduled a news conference in Manhattan Thursday after the company's annual meeting of stockholders. It would be Mr. Ferris's first such meeting since United Airlines' pilots offered three weeks ago to buy the huge carrier for $4.5 billion. UAL said the carrier was not for sale.

headline: LOOKING BEYOND THE CURRENCY QUICK-FIX
abstract: LEAD: THE dollar continues to confound and confuse. Has it fallen too much or too little? Must it be stabilized or drop further?

headline: AN UNLIKELY LAB FOR FREE MARKETS
abstract: LEAD: ON a continent known for protectionism and government control over the economy, Chile's controversial effort to create a market economy is finally showing signs of success after a drastic collapse in 1982 and 1983.

headline: Canada Backs Lumber Pact
abstract: LEAD: A lumber agreement with the United States, in which Canada agreed to impose a 15 percent export tax on softwood exports, has been approved by the House of Commons.

abstract: LEAD:           THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   IV Q'86   III Q'86   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,696.1   $3,686.4   $3,622.3               Real G.N.P. headline: SHULTZ VISITS EMBASSY SEDER FOR NOTED SOVIET DISSIDENTS
abstract: LEAD: In even the most tranquil times, the first night of Passover is full of turbulent emotions for the Jews who have been trying to emigrate from the Soviet Union. The words ''next year in Jerusalem,'' pronounced during the traditional seder, have both a hopeful and a hollow sound.

headline: Advertising; Ephron, Raboy, Tsao Wins Furrier Account
abstract: LEAD: Both Ephron, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit and McCaffery & Ratner made fashion connections last week.

headline: WILL OLD MACHINES KILL NEW IDEAS?
abstract: LEAD: THROUGHOUT the scientific establishment, inside the halls of Congress and in corporate suites across America, concern is mounting about the inadequacy of laboratory equipment and facilities in the nation's universities.

headline: BankAmerica Plea
abstract: LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation, which has been plagued with losses because of problem loans, asked Japanese commercial banks today to buy $350 million in notes and preferred stock as part of a $1 billion package to raise badly needed cash. Frank Newman, BankAmerica vice chairman, met with representatives of 20 banks at a hastily convened session.

headline: Taking a Cue From the Euromarkets
abstract: LEAD: THE recent Treasury proposal on ''superbanks'' rightly acknowledges that banking and financial services is a global industry that the United States cannot expect to dominate in the future simply because it dominated in the past. If our banks are to compete in the coming decades, they will need to be freed of some of the regulatory strictures that have hampered their growth.

headline: Panhandle Eastern Ends Contract
abstract: LEAD: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation said that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company had terminated its contract with the natural gas company after the two sides failed to agree on price. Anadarko said its subsidiary, Pan Eastern Exploration, and Panhandle Eastern had tried to renegotiate the terms of about 40 previous gas contracts since

headline: U.S. LAWS OFFER LESS PROTECTION THAN THOSE OF MAJOR TRADING PARTNERS
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the Corning Glass Works were outraged when they discovered that Sumitomo Electric Industries of Japan was using, without permission, their patented manufacturing process to make optical fiber, the thin glass wires widely used in telecommunications.

headline: Executives Shift At Security Pacific
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had promoted several senior executives in connection with the company's expansion into interstate banking. Robert H. Smith, the company's vice chairman, will also become president and chief executive of the Security Pacific National Bank.

headline: Bonds Plunge, but End Higher
abstract: LEAD: The bond market staged a dramatic comeback yesterday after another plunge in prices earlier in the session.

headline: McFARLANE UNDER OATH: HE CHARTS A PLUNGE INTO PARALYSIS; THE MEANING OF AN AMENDMENT
abstract: LEAD: At one point in his testimony, Mr. McFarlane was asked whether Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's activities complied with the Boland amendment:

headline: THE POLLARD AFFAIR: SPEAKING FRANKLY
abstract: LEAD: Mark Saltzman is a 35-year-old New York songwriter who always considered himself Jewish, but needed a trip to Israel to establish that identity ''beyond maztoh ball soup and even beyond religion.'' Philip Heimowitz, a Wall Street lawyer, has been secure in his Orthodox Judaism all his life.

headline: A SHOWDOWN IN GULF WAR?
abstract: LEAD: When President Reagan meets this week to discuss policy in the Persian Gulf with his national security advisers, he will have to make a crucial decision: Is the United States prepared to bomb Iran to protect Kuwait's ships?

headline: Orders Up 4.3% at U.S. Factories
abstract: LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods, led by heavy demand for military equipment, shot up 4.3 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the best showing in five months.

headline: Flying Pains
abstract: LEAD:  To the Editor:

headline: BID RAISED TO $110 FOR GENCORP
abstract: LEAD: An investor group led by Wagner & Brown of Texas and AFG Industries of California tentatively sweetened its takeover bid for Gencorp Inc. yesterday by $225 million, raising its offer to $2.46 billion.

headline: Chip Merger to Join 2 Respected Chiefs
abstract: LEAD: The merger announced last week between Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Monolithic Memories Inc. will bring together two of the most respected chief executives in the semiconductor industry - Advanced Micro's showman, W. J. Sanders 3d, and Monolithic's Irwin Federman, a self-described ''green-eyeshade type.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE REBELS SAID TO RAID A ZIMBABWE VILLAGE, KILLING 11
abstract: LEAD: Rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance attacked a small village in far northeastern Zimbabwe Saturday night, killing 11 villagers and leaving pamphlets warning that there would be further attacks, witnesses said today.

headline: Marchers in East Jerusalem Back Inmates' Hunger Strike
abstract: LEAD: Protesters marched through East Jerusalem today in support of a hunger strike by Palestinian prison inmates.

headline: INDIAN FLOTILLA IS TURNED BACK BY SRI LANKAN NAVAL VESSELS
abstract: LEAD: An Indian flotilla of fishing boats bound for northern Sri Lanka with food and medicine for ethnic Tamils abruptly called off its mission tonight and turned back after Sri Lankan naval vessels barred it from proceeding.

headline: Name Change By Refco L.P.
abstract: LEAD: Refco Partners L.P., a primary dealer in government securities, has changed its name to Brophy, Gestal, Knight & Company L.P. It is one of 40 firms recognized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as an active participant in the system's open-market operations.

headline: IS IT REALLY THE PRESIDENT? THE WAITER THINKS SO
abstract: LEAD: Some people thought that the man staying at Villa Condulmer, a three-story 17th-century country hotel with bright green awnings, was a double, and that the real American President was in Aviano, a town in Friuli to the east.

headline: ITLAY'S GOVERNMENT FALLS AND A JUNE ELECTION IS CALLED
abstract: LEAD: President Francesco Cossiga dissolved the Italian Parliament tonight, ending a bitter eight-week political crisis. The Government then ordered general elections for June 14.

headline: REAGAN PUTS OFF A SALE TO SAUDIS OF 1,600 MISSILES
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration bowed today to fierce Congressional opposition and withdrew a proposal to sell 1,600 Maverick air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia.

headline: Warsaw Commandos Storm Bus and Overpower Hijacker
abstract: LEAD: A four-hour airport drama ended here this afternoon when Polish commandos stormed a bus on the airport tarmac and overpowered a young Pole who had commandeered it and was threatening to kill passengers with a grenade unless he was flown to the West.

headline: PATENTS; A Cancer Treatment
abstract: LEAD: A method of treating breast cancer is disclosed in a patent granted this week to Dr. Fernand Labrie of Quebec. According to patent 4,666,885, a combined anti-hormonal treatment includes blocking ovarian secretions by surgical or chemical means and adding an anti-androgen such as flutamide. A number of clinical patients have been treated by the process.

headline: MEXICO IS BRUSHED BY CONTRA AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: In what newspapers here are calling ''the Mexican connection'' to the Iran-contra affair, the Mexican political establishment and its right-wing opposition are trading charges that each has maintained improper contacts with American organizations supplying aid to anti-Sandinista forces in Nicaragua.

headline: Uruguayan Clears Up 'State of Siege' Killing
abstract: LEAD: One day almost 17 years ago, Dan Mitrione, an American police adviser, was kidnapped by Tupamaro guerrillas as he left his house in suburban Carrasco. Ten days later, his body was found in an abandoned car.

headline: U.S. Concern Over the Dollar
abstract: LEAD: FINANCIAL markets have had their eyes trained all week on the meetings in Washington of the major industrial countries and the policy-making bodies of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in an effort to see what they mean for the future of the dollar, interest rates and security or insecurity of world debt.

headline: DOLLAR PLUMMETS A DAY AFTER ALLIES SET STABILITY GOAL
abstract: LEAD: The dollar plunged to new lows against the Japanese yen yesterday, just one day after the United States and its economic allies had pledged to stabilize currency rates.

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Campaign Impresses the Chinese
abstract: LEAD: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt was invited to the Third World Advertising Congress in Beijing to present a campaign for a fictional product for the edification of some 2,000 guests at the Great Hall of the People.

headline: New Wine Company Chooses 2 Agencies
abstract: LEAD: After a whirlwind agency search, the newborn Vintners Internatonal Company, which acquired most of Seagram's wine brands, has chosen SSC&B to promote Paul Masson and Great Western Champagne, and Avrett, Free & Ginsberg to promote Taylor California Cellars and Taylor New York Champagne.

headline: 16 Philippine Soldiers Die in a Rebel Ambush
abstract: LEAD: At least 16 soldiers were killed and several were wounded today when Communist rebels ambushed a military convoy in the central Philippines, the military said.

headline: Caesars Takeover Venture Called Off
abstract: LEAD: The New York investor Martin T. Sosnoff said two Dallas-based concerns had ended talks with him on a joint venture to acquire Caesars World Inc. In a statement, Mr. Sosnoff said talks with the Pratt Hotel Corporation and the Southmark Corporation, a real estate developer, had not been actively pursued since they were announced on March 20.

headline: SOVIET, IN A SHIFT, EXPANDS CONTACT WITH THIRD WORLD
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union, in what some diplomats view as a major shift in foreign policy, is seeking increased leverage in developing regions by courting influential non-Marxist nations.

headline: Japanese Make Roads, and Inroads, in Africa
abstract: LEAD: Asaji Kurosawa, the son of a Japanese rice farmer, decided last year to see a bit of the world. Today, he builds low-income housing in this West African village.

headline: CHILE AFTER THE POPE: A MOOD OF ACCOMMODATION
abstract: LEAD: A mood of accommodation has swept the Chilean political scene in the week since the Pope's visit, with all sides publicly expressing a desire to end the polarization.

headline: Montana Agency's Refunding Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Montana Department of Highways is tentatively offering $150 million of refunding highway revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 7.173 percent for a 7 1/8 percent issue due in 2005, at a price of 99 1/2.
